Management are actually down to earth people but get on your case not because they want to but because they have to. 

The systems HSBC use are so outdated it looks like windows 1998. They take forever to load and are constantly crashing it’s embarrassing in front of customers. 

Low salary compared to the same job elsewhere in other banks.

It’s a very boring job you’ll find yourself standing around most of the time or fixing issues around your account openings. 

Progression is slow and if you rent out/ live out it’s hard to get by especially in London

Bad tactics used to sell things people don’t need such as credit cards and loans. 

People resign so quickly here. When I started people who were in my branch for about 6 months resigned as they said the job was boring and could not live off the pay.

review_title: Great Benefits, Good Work/Life Balance, High Senior Management Turnover, Constant Firedrills, Senior Management Clueless
job_title: AML Manager in New York, NY
pros:
- Outstanding benefits: Very competitive salaries, significant 401k matching, BlueCross/BlueSheild insurance plans, MetLife Dental, ability to work from home (so you never have to burn a sick day), terrific amount of vacation days a year.
- CORE Leave: You MUST take 10 consecutive business days off a year. Some firms won't even allow you to do this, but here it is a requirement!
- Relatively easy to make lateral moves. You can apply for new positions internally after a year at your current post, or earlier if you have managerial approval.
cons:
- Senior management must not be getting very competitive bonuses, because they are always in and out within a year.
- Poor communication between senior management and Group executives in the UK, which result in sudden, "important" projects with EXTREMELY tight deadlines. Constantly.
- Who still uses Lotus Notes instead of Outlook? This bank does.
- Poor, poor "training." Usually required a few times a year. Wastes of time.
- The bank is undergoing some big changes due to the recent AML fines, so there is a lot of cloak and dagger talks with senior management constantly filing in and out of various meetings.

review_title: Competitive pay, absolutely awful culture, bland, a company comprised of all nameless/faceless middle management types
job_title: Vice President, Premier Relationship Manager in New York, NY
pros: I found that HSBC paid more handsomely than other global banks in the same tier.  When I worked there, they were more liberal with employee expenses than other comparable banks.
cons: Be prepared to be micromanaged.  It is corporate culture at it's worst, don't know if that stems from being a British bank or just weak management.  It seemed like it was a company comprised of all middle management types, not a ton of all stars there, not very inspiring.  The culture predicates you must look out for yourself, even if it's at the expense of a colleague.  There is a lot of button pushing.  At times, I felt like management was more concerned about completing menial activity tracking tasks as opposed to actually generating revenue.  You have a role and you are expected to only act within said role.  There is no allowance for creativity, thinking outside the box, or taking an entrepreneurial role to your job.  Very rigid structure, everybody just tries to manage up, which is ironic bc everybody seems to be a low level manager.  People there work scared.  Major disconnect between the various divisions of the bank.

review_title: HSBC is THE best global company to work for hands down!
pros: HSBC has many reasons why it's one of the best places to work: strong brand committment, strong ethical values, respectful to the environment, investing in the employees, and good communicaiton, good benefits, and meritocratic performance management.  Some of the brightest people in the corporate global population are here at HSBC.  The culture is in some ways like other financial institutions but different in that a senior management truly cares about the engagement of the employees - are they happy, would they recommend HSBC, would they stay at HSBC.  Environmentally, I feel like they are leading the charge.  A new headquarters in Illinois is a prime example - from cisterns on roof to collect rainwater for toilets to a cafeteria that is green to energy and paper saving strategies.  The green effect cascades to the consumer as well with less direct mail compared to other companies.
cons: It's a global company and you feel the size when planning initiatives that span regions or continents.  An example of this feeling is sheer paperwork and meetings.  It's a facet that most people in regionalized or local companies don't feel.  It's not necessarily a bad thing but part of doing business.

- Most senior positions are filled by managers seconded from other countries.  These positions are only 2 years in length, hence these managers won't bother with developing people.
- One can basically find all the bad examples and general problems discussed in an Organization Behavior textbook right here in HSBC.

review_title: Experience of working here is negatively correlated with your ambition
pros: Very generous time off. Above-average medical, 401k. Great group of colleagues from all over the world. Some flexibility for remote work.
cons:
Most of the actual work is done by a small cadre of employees at the lower and middle levels. I am referring to the type of work that is foundational and encourages success for the business. These are the people in office working and/or online constantly.

The other type of employee can be at lower, middle or upper level of the business. They orbit around the ones who do the work. Especially at upper levels, they make desultory comments on what is put in front of them (this unwillingness to understand means even good ideas are executed badly), and spend their days co-opting the work on meetings and business trips.

You may get glowing performance reviews, but it is often a relatively inexpensive way to keep you where management needs you, because their lifestyle depends on it. You soon realize your career involves subsidizing other peoples' careers. A true shame if you actually love what you do and are good at it.

review_title: Not a bad place for the money if if you're willing to be a robot.
pros: Established stable company.  Good benefits.  Reasonable to good compensation.  Company is well respected globally, even if the brand awareness in the US is low.  Great place to work if you are interested in working overseas.  Many different business units/lines means there is opportunity to move laterally as well as move up.  Company invests in training and development for employees.
cons: Sr mgmt doesn't understand the US market or consumer financial services, vs traditional banking.   Company really doesn't value innovation or entrepreneurial thinking. Increasing reliance of centralized decision making, relegating US employees to be execution artists, not strategists.  Increasingly less tolerant of risk, even when the rewards can be huge.  Bias towards hiring former consultants and valueing that skillset/mindset vs a more diverse workforce.  A lot of lip service is paid to diversity, but little is done.  Not a good place to ascend if you are female; heavy male bias outside of the HR dept.  Company is outsourcing and offshoring more and more of its operations.

review_title: Interesting, varied and very multicultural environment but huge bureaucracy and office politics are rife.
pros: The footprint of the firm is huge in terms of market segment, geography, products and services so a fabulous place to learn your trade as an international banker.  If you can maintain your momentum through the ranks then a varied and interesting career can develop into senior management.
cons: Lines of communication are stretched and confused.  The amount of bureaucracy and waste is huge.  The business is prone to drift, stifled by unimaginative "safe" middle managers prone to shuffle reporting lines while maintaining the status quo.  The performance related pay model is broken with disproportionate pay and bonuses awarded to a minority of staff for mediocre or marginal (subjective) achievements at the expense of team performance.  Hence, what happens on a day to day basis in the front line often fails to match the laudably positive and dynamic "vision" statements set out by senior executives.  This can lead to frustration on a number of levels if you are the type of person who likes to make a difference and achieve tangible improvements in terms of profits, costs, service quality, etc. as part of an effective "team".

pros: Some of the best HR policies in the industry with great work culture and lots of fun activities. Company values inspire individuals to give their best and get them engaged as they know the purpose and how their contribution matters. Work life balance is good. One of the best policy is the ten working days mandatory off in an year when you are completely away from work.
cons: Compensation strategy could be better as there is a huge disparity within teams. Management should recognize real performers and not just smart workers who butter their bosses. There are some people who cannot project themselves but really sweat it out for the team and contribute to the success of business. Sadly that goes unnoticed due to the politics people play. A good Manager / Leader should be able to recognize which team member works and who doesn't but yaps...

job_title: Customer Due Diligence Officer in Montreal, QC
pros:
Fair pay and great benefits package
Various Employee Resource Groups: Celebrate diversity and allow employees to get involved
Possibility of international opportunities
cons: Their management style, at least in my team, encourages silos and seperation amongst team members. In attempts to save costs, decisions are made that complicate processses as opposed to simplifying them. An increasing reliance of offshore team has diminished the quality of our work. They attempt to standardize work that cannot be standardized! They also are obsessed with data - how much work you are completing, how many minutes you spend on a task, etc. Sometimes complying with their tracking tools takes more time than the work itself. Their processes are disorganized and leave room for interpretation causing endless debates over what is the right way to do something. They constantly change priorities. You may spend hours working on something only to be told it is no longer important and there goes all your effort down the drain! Overall, very frustrating working for them.

Felt a sense of dictatorship right from recruitment to production. Managers are in their own world. No guidance or connect with the team. Too many donts and practically no freedom to make choices. Not the least, too much work load. Although the lunch break is one hour, you end up doing your followup work during that time so technically there is hardly any time to take a breather. review_title: Fairly good place to work, depending upon the department
pros:
1. Adopts latest technologies much faster than other big corporates.
2. Good salary hikes, additional performance based bonus above CTC, good rewards and recognitions system.
3.  Allows employees to transfer to other departments, no Manager approval required, after 12 months working in one dept.
4. Plenty of  leave options. Mandatory 2 weeks of continuous leave per year.  Optional 6 months sabbatical after 5 years of continuous service.
5. Good learning options. Access to Safari, Coursera, LinkedIn Learning etc. Regularly holds hackathons and coding competitions with good prizes.
cons:
1. Visibility & opportunities varies from department to department. This is not linked with the performance of the dept in terms of profit provided to the company by that dept.
2.  Very limited travel opportunities. Few people travel multiple times, others are not given any chance.
3. Core functionalities are still running on old legacy systems, making integration with newer applications a nightmare. Very little effort put to modernise those systems. 
4. Terrible facilities in both Hyderabad and Pune offices. LCC Hyderabad campus has limited parking - only 4 days in a week, resulting in illegal parking on the narrow road to office. Inadequate lifts in Pune office. Poor and expensive food in canteens.  Management turns blind eye to these issues.

pros: The work-life balance was superb, the team were great, the work was interesting and the stakeholders were demanding but fair.  Overall the culture is strong - perhaps too strong at times, being inflexible in places - and, despite it being extremely challenging at times, it was an experience I will remember fondly for years to come.
cons: The pressure on the business (not in the Communications world) was overwhelming for many and the regulatory strain is evident in some people's behaviour.  The company is quite restricted (in terms of being able to grow at the rate it plans to) by the regulations in place and the DPA it operates under, and, while I was there, the turnover of employees in key roles made it difficult to have any kind of continuity to drive some of the large programmes.  All of that said, if you want a good challenge, are willing to work hard to reap the rewards and have resilience, all of this will pale into insignificance.

review_title: Stay away unless you don't care about job security
pros: Global Brand? Maybe that's it
cons:
HSBC has been on a significant cost-cutting program for nearly 6 years now. It's the same old year after year cutting FTE around 150 per year and bring people back the following year because they cut too many people.

I was with HSBC for 15 years and finally left because the environment is absolutely disgusting.

Because of nonstop layoffs in the Vancouver office - everyone is throwing each other under the bus to try and save themselves. On top of that, the situation has become so dire that Management has started communicating to all managers that they need to artificially lower staff ratings to poor performers because they do not have any budget to continue laying off staff. This now creates a false image of staff being poor performers so they can be let go with just cause. This needs to be clearly communicated to all staff to ensure appropriate legal action is taken.

This year specifically management was pushing "Project Oak" which essentially made all staff hunt down individuals to cut. It's become a circus and almost sad as all management is throwing each other under the bus to try and save themselves.

I know of 5 individuals who have launched lawsuits directly with HSBC Bank Canada - and they have now produced lie after lie to try and hide their behavior.

My suggestion is for everyone to stay clear of this mess.

review_title: Perks are good if you can survive it
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Buffalo, NY
pros:
Time off/vacation - They will work with you if they can and plenty of paid time off, even in your first year,
Benefits - Way better than any other employer I've had. 
Pay - They pa y well for entry-level, although they find ways to pay out less and less each year in bonuses.
Plenty of overtime available
cons: They find reasons to fire people. I was a top sales associate and they fired me for doing the same thing others were doing without warning and two days from a promotion. I was supposed to have been promoted within a year, but they kept changing the requirements and new associates were being hired into those positions before I could meet those new requirements. You see people get walked out every week for one reason or another. Communication is horrible between management, branches and the call center. They keep outsourcing more and more overseas to India and the Phillipines and lay off entire departments constantly (ie Card Security, E-Mail teams, mortgage). review_title: My experience with Household Insurance Svcs was a rewarding one.

Some employees do not have the finances or means to be able to continue their education.

No role models at the top. A lot of slackers get away with it and have been there their whole career. The way variable compenstation is calculated is completely intransparent.  You're just a number and replaceable anyway.  Hot-desking adds to an impersonal environment.  No contact to HR ever, except when things go wrong.

review_title: Global franchise that needs more commitment to local businesses
job_title: Research Analyst in New York, NY
pros: It is truly a global franchise and promotes its employees to think globally. At least with my manager, he/she tries to ensure employees are satisfied and have a good work/life balance, particularly since compensation is constrained. Generally (but especially applicable to large firms like HSBC), if your manager is competent and fights for his/her staff, then employees become more motivated to succeed.
cons: Where do I begin...first off technology/IT infrastructure and staff needs massive improvement. Overall, employee turnover, across all levels of the group, are extremely high. Part of the reason is the lack of accountability and high amount of strategic changes, which prompts management shake ups. The big downside of being a global firm is that executives in London do not fully understand or appreciate the challenges facing the local businesses. And bringing in management from London is often not effective, especially since these managers are temporary (stints last 2-5 years) and does not instill any sense of stability.

review_title: HSBC-US: The Red-Headed Stepchild of HSBC Holdings
pros:
-Not chained to the branch.

-Encouraged to network and attend business seminars/functions to earn more business. 

-Good work/life balance for the most part.

-HSBC looks good on a resume (at least for now).
cons:
-HSBC-US Business Banking is slowly but surely becoming widget-focused despite HSBC's preference for higher-end clientele.  

-Too many different systems, MCD, CSM, CIF, Callidus, etc.

-Callidus is a train wreck that reports incentive incorrectly so you are forced to track down what you should be getting paid.  If you don't pay close attention, you might not get paid correctly.

-Obstructionist, drawn out, laborious, tedious, hours-long account opening procedures.

-Extremely intimidated by government regulators. 

-Ridiculously conservative lending.

-Not a good place for most salespeople.

pros: I worked with HSBC retail banking for over 12 years in 3 different middle east countries and I always got management support whenever my family move to different country. I always got the support needed and my last role was handling the Premier department in the 3 countries.
cons:
Unfortunately, moving to the  US, since I have obviously  a different experience, after several trials to reach directly to staff working in the branch, no one was willing to even interview me for an informative meeting or willing to fit me in any entry level job in commercial banking to continue with the group, Although I had an outstanding performance over 12 years and candidate level 3 in the CFA program.
 Applying directly through HSBC career site was disappointing as regional HR just decline applicants if not matching the exact requirement.

job_title: GCB3 (Junior Rank of Senior Management) in London, England
pros:
Great opportunities to learn, grow and progress. There is generally support to broaden your career and expand international experience -- but it takes a lot of hard work and sacrifice to realise it.

When HSBC finally decides to do something, they do it.
cons:
There's a strong "we do it ourself" culture at HSBC. This is sometimes positive, but often turns projects into expensive elongated affairs that seldom come to conclusion when they need to.

There is a significant tension in the corporate ranks between "global" and "local", and a less tense but ever-present UK/Hong Kong leadership tension.

It it's a bureaucratic place, steeped in traditions, held back but the scar tissue of multiple acquisitions and divestments. Insiders often suggest hay HSBC means How Simple Became Complicated.

review_title: Staty away if you are in IT
pros: If you want to work for a behemoth organization and just be a face in the crowd then go for it. Before the financial crisis struck job security was fairly good, especially in IT where I worked so that could have been another reason lot of people, particularly in Vancouver, Canada remained stuck in their positions.
cons: From an IT perspective, it's a career killer. The technology leadership team is incompetent and only acts as yes-men telling the CIO what he wants to listen. The Household team (includes the CIO) is in charge and they're trotting out the same dog and pony show before business year after year.  IT is touted as a force for change but status quo reigns supreme and there's no clear understanding of what business benefits IT changes can bring. Bottomline, If you're looking for a dynamic, fast-paced, forward-looking career it IT, this ain't the place to work.

review_title: It is a good place to work, and overall has been a good company to me.
pros: Good benefits, profit sharing plans. Very flexible with schedule and understanding when time off needed. A lot of rewards and recognition programs with various bonuses(some are very lucrative) and prizes that could be won, and as well as a a monthly bonus system ranging from up to $1000 a month. Management values diversity and has several committees and tries to get employees involved. Green Team, and Fun team are two of them. Values sustainability. Management is expected to constantly train employees. Metric evaluations are also very detailed.
cons: Management is not always competent and can be rude/powertrip (something consistent after 6 years of working their). Work can be very monotonous. Hard to stay motivated. Sometimes upper management decisions don't always sit well with employees (closing of departments or reducing staff). Sometimes it can seem more like employees are numbers. Not much to complain about just bad managers.  Some policies that employees do not like.

review_title: Good company to work for, but globalisation takes it toll.
pros: Good benefits, in the IT department folks generally get 25-30 days of annual vacation.  People are nice and generally follows a well defined protocol.  Company offers numerous training, but most of them are not technical in nature.  There is flexibility with work hours and working from home is well accepted.
cons: Projects are demanding, personal sacrifice is observed for many flagship projects.  Generally salary is capped early in the career and it is difficult to move up to a higher job band.  Work life balance is difficult to maintain due to global team augmentation model (parts of the team will always be offshore in India, Brazil, or China).  Meetings outside of what is usually considered core hours elsewhere takes place on a regular basis.  The bank tends to be overly receptive of IBM solutions that has a recent track record of undermining employee's productivity.

review_title: Pretty good, but not yet great.
pros: Above average benefits, including vacation time, 401k, tuition reimbursement and health insurance.  This is a global organization, so you could potentially be collaborating and connecting with peers across the globe.  Very conducive for learning and absorbing global strategies.  Pay is aligned with market and is often beyond market value for position.  Telecommuting is encouraged.
cons: The global organization is a double edged sword. The sheer size of this place often makes it difficult to get things done.  There seems to be a never ending "transition" to move out of regional silos and into a more global structure.  Easier said than done.  The struggle is constant and wears on the employees trying to get things done.  No one on the management team (or above) seem to have the answers.  The Elmhurst, IL office is dismal, but a new office space is been constructed in Arlington Heights.

job_title: Sales Assistant in New York, NY
pros: HSBC is a great company with a massive focus on community and wellness. Even in this economy, the bank is in a decent financial status and still manages to offer positive experiences for their employees. While very corporate, there is usually a small group of employees under one specific manager which helps in the individual focus of employees rather than a huge group.
cons: HSBC is a bank that counts where each penny is placed. Granted that the current economic status has pushed these practices farther than ever before, the bank has put a great amount of concentration on each position, each employee and just how they can make tweak them to save money. Slowly, cuts are being made in a very quiet fashion to keep the alarms off. It's a little too sneaky for my liking, especially that in the end, it's not about the employee, it's about their salary. Very "corporate" outlook on the HR end which makes you feel like more of a number rather than the person who puts in those hard hours.

pros: Excellent Benefits - Health, Vacation (4 weeks) and 401k. Great pay package.
cons: The Texas Corporate and Middle Marking Banking office is purely business development office with lack of customers, book of business, continuous improvement (training and development), comprehensive sundry support and infrastructure.  Unlike other global HSBC offices in the world, the Texas office lacks full scale bank, long-term vision and approach.  Short-term and immediately gain precedes growing the HSBC brand and loyalty.  Mandate lack clear vision; employee management and management mission and values do not sync with global HSBC employee management practice, mission and values.  This led to low team mate morale.  Very little help/support from SVPs.  Only Aim - hire and bring revenue immediately.  Also, the Texas office lacks diversity in workforce (key feature of HSBC) and preference/fondness seems to be given to older Caucasian individuals.  Unlike other global brands, diversity is not valued here.

review_title: Little Support to Smaller Retail Branches

Too much micromanaging of the sales team.
Pay increases few and far between, even when annual review is Strong Performer or Role Model. Difficult to reach out to other departments as no phone numbers, only email and you have to know who to send email queries to. Insufficient training and if you end up with an external hire for a branch manager, they can be useless, even after a year and a half. I recently left because of the increased stress causing lack of work life balance - the branch manager should be able to open a bank account for a new client after almost 2 years in the role. The BM is my boss and should not be peppering me with questions or interrupting my overbooked day because she can't figure out how to hook up her webcam or can't navigate the new mutual fund system. Half the staff has left in under a year and 3 of us were directly related to poor branch management

job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Direct manager level is excellent and there is a genuine desire (if you push for it) for opportunities that are lateral.
Work / Life is you are in regulatory is not a benefit (long hours + 12 hour days).
Direct teams are generally friendly, good work atmosphere and work as a team
cons:
There is a lack of fact based decision making at SVP levels and regional heads that creates extreme confusion and complexity in how teams deliver that is politically / self driven. This makes is very difficult for those actually doing the work to meet regulatory deadlines.   
Lack of integration regionally to global (and vice versus) over complicates our approach which leads to multiple teams with multiple different approaches (which then change on a monthly basis). Expensive and inefficient.  Can be frustrating for teams in all regions at the lower levels.
Culture training which has only be US based and top down behaviour into the SVP level is not evidenced / acted upon.
Nearly impossible to gain promotion / real pay for performance.  Quotas are strictly adhered to despite individual performance or your groups.

The benefits are just standard fare for banking (and fading fast) and my work/life balance was non-existent.  All work 24/7 and working from home gets you laid off at the next opportunity.
cons: Too many to list.  Company is run by a cadre of International Managers that occupy all executive management positions and start their careers at the top.  They rotate them around the globe to groom them for Group Head and CEO positions.  The IMs act as a ceiling for career growth as nobody gets into this group unless recruited there out of college.  It also ensures that you will have a new IM running your Business Unit every 2-3 years and that all strategy decisions are based on a 1-2-year time horizon.  Typical direction is to solve complex problems the IMs don't understand at no cost to the company.  No IMs are held accountable for their failure, only those that work under them.

pros: You may win the lottery of keeping your job. But being good and working hard don't matter at HSBC.
cons: Hard work, integrity, praise, don't mean anything to HSBC USA.

pros:
-lots of opportunities, due to high turn over rate
-if manager likes you you get to move up even if you are not qualified. i.e pretty girls.
-benefits are very food even for part-time
-some branches only open till 10-4 but not main office
-learn alot in branch. people in branch really willing to teach.
-rbwm is not too bad. but watch out for the head office jobs.
cons:
-terrible management depending on which department you work in. they don't care about employees work process, when asked for training they say there is none. fyi this is the back office for credit services agency department in toronto.
-I felt racism and discrimination, i voiced out to my manager and he did nothing, I was slowly building depression and when i left I told my manager's manager but i doubt they were doing anything. i end up just quitting
-if your department is busy, expect to stay late while your manager leaves. one of my assistant manager works at home 3-4 days a week because she has kids. never has time to come in. when she does she leaves at 4pm while every body works till 6. she'll come and say, oh i work till very late at night.

pros:
no bench
certifications/external training available
appreciate your contributions related to work
you can bunk offices, go to picnic or remain absent while you are marked present for attendance (oh! there is no attendance system)
you can go onsite & enjoy 9-6 job & enjoy saturday-sunday, if you know java
If you are more skilled then your life is hell as you've to guide everyone in company on those technologies, then 24x7 shift, then attend to shift on holiday/weekends , no onsite, standard hike like everyone in company etc
cons:
can put you to any project while placing you
bounds you to do certifications & other activities in the name TPM (Total Performance management or review) & then makes you cry to redeem it
biased while appreciation. Higher management does not understand why he is appreciating the other 
HR. what HR ? It took almost 3 months to create my salary account at my own bank & that too after lot many escalations/mails/phone calls. Do I need to tell more ?

pros: Set hours and days meant good work/life balance.  Pay and benefits average for industry.  great co-workers.
cons:
Women are treated like they have a specific "place" and don't dare step outside of it.  Woman were never given specific position reserved for men only, which meant lower pay and no chance for advancement.  Those who were at least subservient, were treated more like pets that equals - but was the only way they could at least get somewhere. 

Management was horrible.  One manager used to yell at people in front of everyone.  Another was so afraid to do anything, his department was out of control - HR had to come in because they were actually telling homosexual jokes outloud to passerbys.  

When you were needed, you were treated like gold.  Once you were no longer needed like at the end of a project, you were just discarded to go back to you "place".

review_title: Bad for me, may be ok for you
pros: Often pays more than other Buffalo area banks for same position. Opportunity to work remotely in some positions. Opportunities for international travel if you are into that. Good severance package when laid off.
cons: If you want to work here, do some research on the crimes they committed over the last twenty years. Maybe this will present an ethical conflict for you, and maybe it won't. While some individual managers are ok, the company is not. EVP-level and up treats employees like interchangeable parts.  The benefits package seems pretty good but it is really just what one should be able to expect from any employer -- PTO, health etc. Back when HSBC was still Marine Midland, it was a great place to work. Now there are a lot of people still there who are justifiably bitter over the company's decline. It's a huge transnational corporation and as such it lays people off routinely. There are people who have worked there for thirty years, but I doubt anyone starting this year will be around that long,

review_title: World's local bank and a great employer.
job_title: Credit Risk Analyst in Buffalo, NY
pros: HSBC is a financial behemoth, and despite the Household International acquisition, is still risk-adverse and proactive.  Obviously not untouched in the current economic climate, HSBC has acted before many of its competitors to head-off bad debt losses.  My experience at HSBC was very position.  Management is very hierarchically arranged, as is to be expected at a bank, and is sometimes slow to change.  After observing other organizations, while HSBC sometimes lacks the willingness to make necessary information technology investments, the ability to adapt to change in this organization is above average.  I really felt like a part of the team at HSBC.
cons: Management's long tenure with the bank leads to a very safe, but stodgy atmosphere.  Specifically, when considering international expat assignments, one must be "a good old boy" for consideration.

review_title: Working here is a mixed bag, overall a good place with great people
job_title: Assistant Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros: HSBC offers a great benefit package with several choices on medical insurance / drug coverage. Tuition reimbursment is also offered. The work is interesting and keeps me thinking and learning. There is opportunity for posting into different positions in order to keep on learning and growing. There are recognition programs in place which help to stimulate that competive spirit. Training for the entry level positions such as collections, credit and Customer Care have evolved over time to be best in class.
cons: Income growth is limited by a rather stingy pay for performance policy. There is a curve grading system in place for yearly reviews. This works well for large departments such as Collections, Care. Not so good for smaller groups which are lumped in with larger areas who do not do comparable work. For some no matter how well you perform your rating will not exceed average. Staff reductions when they have happened have not been handled in the best possible way.

pros: Fair compensation, despite the difficulties in the banking industry. For the Philippines, the medical benefits package is second to none, in my opinion. Employees are encouraged to speak their minds. Exposure to other countries and cultures - diversity and inclusion is a truth in HSBC, not just a catchphrase. Opportunities to go on short term attachment abroad. Management acknowledges need for change.
cons: In terms of change initiatives, satellite sites (non-regional hub countries such as the Philippines) come last in the chain. Management makes an effort to execute changes based on employees feedback, but their efforts fall flat due to various reasons (lack of understanding of how the process performs on the ground level, regional politics, budget constraints, etc). High turnover and attrition adds stress to remaining employees, with management having to ask for approval to replace the headcount, usually with little success, so overtime of 2-3 hours is the norm. The cost savings goal and barrage of change initiatives is negatively impacting the employees' ability to do BAU, much less execute the change.

review_title: Run, run as fast as you can!
job_title: Assistant Vice President  in Austin, TX
pros:
Global company but good luck going global if you are less than district manager. Good luck becoming 
district manager within first 10 years of employment.  Benefits are thr best and tme off allowance is great.
cons: Hours we work are long. There is no support from middle managment and when it is time to take a fall branch manager is the on- unless you are the favorite of one of the higher ups. In that case you can do what you want. Not good company for women small percentages get anywhere and many women managers go through much more scruitny than men.

pros:
- Good Maternity Benefit (16 weeks)
- Good Medical Benefit including your spouse and kids
- Good Staff Mortgage loan . 0.8% interest rate and the loan can up to 120 of your monthly salary
cons:
- Retail Banking environment still embedded in traditional management, no VPN provided for RM, so home office policy is not efficient since no access to work.
- Take a long time to get your Work Phone or Work SIM card set up ..very hard to achieve your office email while you are out of office.
- BMs/ BSMs are micromanagement, eg check your sign in time, sign out time, lunch time, outreach time etc...
- RMs don't have a regular seat, most of the seats are mobile assignment
- if RMs need help for sales flow or SQ issue, hard to find a mentor for guidance and solution, all depends on different person opinions (which easily lead to SQ issue identify)

review_title: The best place for work-life balance and career progress
pros: The best place to work for job satisfaction and for maintaining your health.  Hard work is recognized and compensated well, with incentives etc. You will enjoy the work, if you are a people person, the colleagues are all very nice, the customers are also mostly very good.  If you are lucky, you will be in a good team and you will have good progress. Overall, you will enjoy working here.  Management is very mature and the hierarchy is not overly complicated.  You stand reasonable chances for promotion if you are a good performer.  Though, you will find some who are involved in low level politics, be assured they will not get any benifits out of that as the interviews are conducted for all IJP's by some others, whom they would not even know.
cons: Nothing much in particular, salaries could have been better

review_title: First fault - don't make it a double fault
pros: No real workpressure - so one can maintain Work-life Balance. Until and Unless you want to take it on yourself to change things - they continue the way they are.
cons: Laidback attitude of people towards work. No real process improvements in the last so many years. Because of the geographic spread the bank sustains otherwise it would have been the pioneer to initiate the reccession. Salary is meagre - at least in APAC. The attitude of the European counterparts stinks when talking to the workforce in the APAC region (esp Brits) - maybe becoz of their insecurity of losing jobs. The culture of the organisation is not instilled and communicated across the organisation effectively.

pros: The graduate program is totally worth it. The sky is your limit, especially if your point of hire is in Europe, North and South America as well as Hong Kong to some extent. As far as my knowledge goes, hitherto HSBC Australia is yet to have one and doesn't even acknowledge the program. One of the big loopholes that the Group must solve.
cons:
Office politics is entrenched in some sites, on the upside this is a good place to hone your soft skills.
I have a bad experience with how my works and experience were not acknowledged at all in HSBC Australia when I applied for different available roles which were very similar roles with the ones that I've done in couple HSBC's sites.

review_title: Good progression but not much loyalty benefits
pros: If you're hard working you can go far and there's always opportunities for the right people to progress. Big organisation so if you get bored of your job you can switch to an entirely different department doing a completely different thing while still staying under the same company. Big on meritocracy.
cons:
Not much incentive to stay working there. My plan is to move to somewhere who offers me better benefits and rewards when the time is right. Staff benefits include health insurance and a good pension plan but strangely no decent staff offers on mortgages, credit cards, etc. which is a shame, makes it hard for you to be an advocate of the bank. I still bank with Nationwide personally!

Also sometimes the organisation can feel *too* big. The systems are about 30 years out of date and it's near impossible to get any change going!

review_title: Poor senior decision making wastes money, puts pressure on middle management and teams
pros:
Some BRILLIANT individuals, totally committed
Good external brand, though tarnished in recent years
Good overall package
Great location in Canary Wharf if you want to be in the buzz of the finance district
Great shopping underground
Great place for contractors and big consultancy businesses - a license to print money!
cons:
Poor internal computer systems, not integrated, wastes a huge amount of time
Very poor senior decision making - takes forever to get approvals, and then decisions get changed / go back to the beginning and start again!
Waste a SIGNIFICANT amount of money on projects which go round in circles and don't deliver

review_title: Good name to have on your CV if that's what you're looking for.
job_title: Assistant Human Resources Manager  in Hong Kong
pros:
Secure, stable, established. Would be a good place to try if you want to see what it's like in a really big bank.
Lots of benefits such as food and beverage, special offers etc. afforded by the bulk of the employee population.
Has very high level of brand-recognition at least in Hong Kong.
cons:
Probably too big to manage effectively. Everyone pretty much becomes a cog in the machine, unless you become senior management or happen to work in a fairly independent division / location.
With such size, it's difficult to avoid bureaucracy. At least in Hong Kong, back-office functions can be so narrowly defined, while overseeing a complex range of customers, that no one really has the 'big picture'.
There often is a disconnect between what top level management sees and what actually happens at the working level. e.g. organisation of divisions is viewed differently depending on the level it is viewed by.

pros: best things is work life balance. It is best place for those who want to live their career in single setup/framework, don't want to learn new things and happy with doing same thing every day and who want to do lots of CSR and team building exercises. jobs are very safe even in the recession time. working for a respectable  banking brand
cons: middle management is not fair in dealing with work force, lacks innovative management approach and not interested in improving the current situation. If any suggestion is given, usually no action is taken.  opportunities are not equal to every employee. If you don't ask things, you will never get it whether promotion or onsite. HSBC GLT does not match to the reputation of the banking brand of HSBC

pros: Work in a professional environment. Some staff seem to be smart so working with others whom are educated and smart is a nice. Learning the ins and outs of Corporate America/Global Corporation.
cons: The norm of the expectation to work long hours and some weekends. Upper Management especially the Senior Officer promotes a negative work environment by constant threat of job loss, Point the finger and blame kind of attitude, and because of this trickles down to other upper management and so they learn and act from the top down.

review_title: A good place to start or finish your career with
job_title: Audit Manager in New York, NY
pros:
- generous time off program
- global scale provides ample career opportunities
- supportive of remote work and work-life balance
cons:
- typical politics and "who you know" circle of things to get to where you want. although they revamped performance management, the process is still jaded
- typically, those who rise to the top are the "talkers" vs. the "walkers"
- management decisions constantly made under committees representing both local and global management lines (Band 2 or higher) which overburden and slow processes to a crawl. Mid-level management decisions have been stripped or replaced. 
- unrealistic expectations to carry out unprecedented changes at "zero tolerance" levels

review_title: Laid back atmosphere with great resources available
pros:
- Great resources available, totally global working environment
- Low work load with very few crunch situations
- Excellent on-site leadership
- Highly valued brand-name in KPO industry (and only in KPO industry and not in front end banking)
Maybe an excellent firm to settle down with when you do not intend to take too much load in life.
cons:
- Changes are too frequent, something which is of priority might become redundant tomorrow making all your efforts go in waste
 - firm is almost always in phase of restructuring
 - Management is short sighted with very few people who could lead or think of something long term
 - too much politics involved which affects appraisals as well as raises
 - Bad paymaster, Disparity of salary within teams for no justifiable reasons
- Firm has earned too much bad name off late which might put you in uncomfortable position when interacting with outside world (Money laundering, withdrawal seizer etc)

job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: For most people, work life balance is probably the best thing about working here.  In some units, it's mandatory due to lack of space.  Some offices look like ghost towns on Fridays.  And most are out by 5 pm.   Besides that, the pay is decent, 401k and benefits are good, and most people are nice.
cons: Too many people work from home too often, which reduces productivity.  This is an issue for a company that continues to struggle.  Some areas are overstaffed while others are understaffed.  Leadership is mediocre and mostly look out for themselves.  Too much time is spent justifying results to London rather than trying to address underlying issues, which creates a lot of work that doesn't drive business decisions.   Lots of bandaid solutions to problems in the hopes that the wounds will heal on their own and business will improve for no reason.

review_title: Great name on your CV, otherwise a political hotbed of mess
pros: Great work-life balance (everyone has a decent lunch, and leaves on time) , great location (green park, amazing in the summer).
cons: For a large company, there is a very small canteen on the bottom floor, which doesnt offer much of a variety. Dont be deluded by the fancy interior to the lobby, the actual working floors are as back dated as a 80s sitcom. The place is a political minefield, if your great at playing the political game you will thrive here. Middle management have ample opportunities to hide and soak the glory and are not held to account. Its a great stepping stone to move onto something more stable, and progressive. If your going to a interview ask them about the results of their recent employee survey.

pros: Worked in the trading floor. Institutional Sales. For two years. Great atmosphere. Great place to learn.
cons: Great atmosphere, yes, for me, because it fit my personality. Although it is 100% cut throat. Salaries and bonuses are terrible compared to other banks. Bonuses are 1/4 to 1/2 of those given by other banks for similar positions/performance. Negotiate well your entry salary, as it will never be raised until you are promoted, unlike other banks that provide yearly raises (which is the norm for global banking and global markets positions in tier 1 banks). Very little mobility = very hard to change teams. Be careful in trusting HR; odds are that if you do, you will get stabbed in the back. There are a lot of legacy employees who are not very capable. And in general most employees are depressed about the stagnant salaries and terrible bonuses. Its called Half Salary Bonus Cut for a very good reason.

review_title: It's a OK place to work
pros: Great international exposure, significant workload that can enrich your experience and colleagues that don't mind helping. Good banking benefits to staff compared to other local banks in Canada however this benefit is on the decline.
cons: Very poor management structure that is confused between going global or staying local. No proper focus on any activity or business process. The technology division is divided into fiefdoms with a small diminishing camp of do'ers and a growing population of only talkers. Limited (read as no)  career opportunities, little to no pay reviews and average bonus. Definitely pay way below market and they don't care, they believe being global gives them access to cheap labour. However with going cheap, quality suffers, Low employee morale across the organisation. Lacks dynamism and definitely hates dynamic employees as they push the envelope that makes sr.management uncomfortable.

job_title: Customer Service Officer in London, England
pros:
Meet some great people, 
can be fun if working in a branch with fun people.
have met colleagues that I am glad to have met and will know them for years to come.
training is good
Hard work is recognised and appreciated
cons:
Too many jobs-worth's who are upset with their lives/careers and so they will do anything to discredit someone who is young, intelligent and doing well. They will act nice to your face and then  stab you in the back. 

Nonsensical and ambiguous rules concerning employee behavior .

Managers will pick and choose who they like. Those that are favoured will be allowed to misbehave  without consequence.

You can get comfortable because the job is easy and you enjoy the atmosphere and time spent with colleagues and therefore you will not be as motivated to move on in your career

They will move you to another branch whenever they like without taking your feelings into consideration. You are just a number to them: disposable; replaceable .

Pay and bonuses are awful

pros:
They treat their staff well
Great knowledge sharing
Fun atmosphere, friendly co-workers and managers. Lots of informal after-work gatherings and everyone was really supportive.
The starting salary is very good and competitive. There is a bonus incentive scheme that can add up to 30% to the salary. There is a pension scheme, mortgage subsidy, participation in share ownership scheme.
Another great thing is the training that HSBC provide. There are loads of courses you could take.
But I think the best about HSBC is that it's a well-run company and will survive and succeed in the long-term perspective.
cons:
There are very few downsides generally, but a few include:
Company is too large, hard to make an impact
Career advancement opportunities can sometimes be limited depending on the business area unless you're you build good contacts within the firm. It could be difficult to move from one business area to another
Feedback and performance reviews could be better.

job_title: Branch Customer Service Representative in Buffalo, NY
pros: HSBC is a decent place to work if you don't mind constant selling pressure. Alot of changes are planned, not sure if they will happen.
cons: We keep hearing how valued we are, and that's great, I love hearing it, but when I asked for a raise after 2.5 years I was asked how it was justified. I said because it's been 2.5 years and I'm now the most senior person here. I was denied a raise and quit for a job that compensated more competitively. Also I just graduated college and applied for jobs in other departments. I'm a fairly talented person, and I work very hard, HSBC never even gave me an interview for any job which I was more than qualified for.

review_title: It Really Depends on the Team You're With
pros:
- Supportive line and entity managers who are happy to give guidance and encouragement, which is especially valuable in navigating the more complicated sides of working in a bank
- Depending on if you're working with the right team and product owners, the freedom to start and pursue new initiatives to drive better customer experience
- A close-knit environment with lots of cross-functional opportunities, which allows for self-enrichment and learning more about what other colleagues are involved in
cons:
- A handful of people are only interested in engaging in office politics rather than producing actual work of value
- Expect approval processes to be drawn out (yes, even for getting a Chrome browser)

review_title: Retirement job...no career and growth ambition ?please join holiday inn...GLT!!
pros:
Captive unit..almost no sever impact if missed deadlines or major defect went in production.
Secure job and slow but stable growth in salary.
Good work life balance encouraged
Perfect for someone looking for stress free environment or working woman with small kid to handle both career and motherhood and household responsibilities.
Big brand in market and really large company and group
Favours in house talent..so fresher's have bright future if ready to work for less salary for some years
cons:
Leadership is not active and spineless
People doing same job for number of years
No promotion policy which is followed here
Someone can become PM in 10 years in company while lateral from other company with 15+ years experience may end up being TL or APM
Pressure of not keeping job but surviving politics

pros: Its a big corporation so if you end up at a right team (not the one I was in), you will get opportunities to apply for roles elsewhere around the world. Its comfortable for someone who prefers quite rigid corporate structure but again it really depends on the team. I struggle to think of the pros - I had some very nice colleagues, a nice view and the gym was in the same building.
cons: In the 5 years I spent in my role I did not get a single promotion (the flat structure of our team, there were people who had been there for longer than me - in the same role). I had one training course that was in my professional field, other than that it was endless compliance, health and safety, AML etc. courses that prominently feature one of the sillier corporate slogans around -  courageous integrity. Yes I don't know what that means either.

job_title: Premier Client Consultant in Buffalo, NY
pros: HSBC has a strong international presence that helps it's overall financial stability.  As a result many clients find it more attractive than other smaller banks.
cons: It's recent restructuring at the end of 2008 has had a negative effect on it's Premier Client Consultants.  Although the hourly rate has increased modestly for these employees they are asked to take on many more tasks that in the past were handled by specialized departments.  As a result these Consultants may not be as proficient at these specialized tasks.  "Premier Customers" (those having over $100,000.00 in the bank) will notice a difference.  The "One Stop Shop" may sound good as a concept but in execution it lacks effectiveness.  Trying to save money by eliminating specialized departments and overloading it's Premier Consultants will only result a diminishing of good customer service.

pros:
The benefits are pretty good. Provides health insurance and stock purchase at a discount.
Work life balance is decent, but largely depending on manager.
A lot of day offs provided per year, even for new employees.
Training is pretty good. A lot of classes offered both technical and non technical.
Employee engagement is good, senior management is trying its best to listen to the low level employees and hear them out.
Fellow employees are pretty friendly and easy to get along with. There is not much cut throat competition.
HSBC offers special banking benefits to employees.
cons:
Promotions is biased. It is based on who brown noses the best and favoritism rather than on merit.
A lot of the managers do not know anything about what they are managing thus making a big joke of everything and leaving everything for the analysts to figure out.
Some managers are strict about taking day offs. Thus negating the purpose of having a lot of day offs. 
Cafeteria food is overpriced and inedible. Work location is in the middle of nowhere - long commute times.

review_title: Great people but below-market salaries and poor leadership provide for an uncertain future.
job_title: Business Relationship Manager in Vancouver, BC
pros: Great colleagues who take the time to train you and to assist you with your job duties. Very knowledgeable senior managers with strong background in the industry. Good number of vacation days. Potentially strong bonus/incentive system. Well respected company with a strong credit culture.
cons: Poor leadership. Very manual processes. Slow career advancement. Below average base salary compensation. Cheap/frugal culture even for a bank. Pay-for-performance culture is unevenly applied with a tendency to reward mediocrity. While the organization is the largest global bank in the market, there are still very limited opportunities to work in another country within the Group, except at the highest levels.

review_title: Very political, but not in a good way. "Best place to work" motto is a bit of a failure.
pros: If you are lucky enough to work for a good manager, it can be an OK place to work. Unfortunately, there are more bad managers with ruthless tactics than good ones. There is not much good I can say about this company. I do not have many good memories of the 8 years I have spent there.
cons: If you are lucky enough to work for a good manager, it can be an OK place to work. Unfortunately, there are more bad managers with ruthless tactics than good ones. There is a big difference between espoused values and reality. Also, moving to new roles, or progressing your career is nearly impossible. Want to move up? It is easier to change companies than move internally into new roles. Long work hours, often without compensation. Work / life balance is a bit of a joke.

review_title: It's not what you know, it's who you know (US office)
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The benefits and perks are pretty good.
cons: They don't promote people who truly deserve it, but if you know someone, you're in.  Office politics suck, and procedures are drowning in red tape.  It takes 6 weeks for 10 people to get email addresses!  I had to say "it's not in my job description" not because I didn't want to do something, but because my manager told me to say that.  Workload is not evenly distributed between peers.  If you don't have the right school on your resume, your chances of getting hired are slim.  Performance reviews are a joke, and a waste of time.

review_title: Good, but sometimes wrong people are in the wrong roles
pros: Generally good. Was given many opportunities that you don't always get elsewhere. International exposure.  Strong business. Great network. Great locations.
cons: Some departments are not managed as well as others.  Lots of politics.  Right now, many wrong people in roles that need better resources.  Too many middle managers trying to tread water and acting as gatekeepers/blocking staff with real knowledge.

pros: The office in Buffalo/Depew is very friendly - lots of people to learn from.  Many job roles give workers the flexibility to work from home at least 2 times a week, mking work life balance easy to manage.  Benefits are very good here - most employees are able to start off with at least 3 weeks of vacation to start.
cons: Upward movement appears to be somewhat difficult unless you switch departments.  Higher level openings are routinely filled by external candidates, and the system for raises appears to be backwards.  If you get a promotion, the max amount your pay can be increased is capped by a certain percentage, leaving people with a long tenure at the bank essentially screwed, pay wise.  Managers would rather pay an external candidate more than give internal candidates the same rate.  Everyone knows the only way to really increase your base rate is to leave and then eventually return.

review_title: How Simple Becomes Complicated - HSBC (Retail Banking)
pros: As with any organisation, you will meet some genuinely nice people and make friends.
cons:
Absolutely terrible management, mostly Alan Sugar wannabe clones, but without an ounce of a clue how to manage people. The only thing keeping it going is the brand name. Genuinely disastrous internal system and communication, often left wondering how the same important decisions are left to a mere 'stab in the dark' and 'hope for the best' time and again as no solutions or huge barriers to them. Often walking a tightrope of risk as a result only to be blamed for any errors.

Customers regularly abuse staff without recourse due to lack of backbone amongst management, who in turn take it out on other staff. An overall very poor environment  which one cannot withstand for longer than a year hence high turnover. It is as if Hsbc is addicted hopelessly to alienating its workforce. But hey..... could be worse right?

pros: Large parent company with lots of capital are still willing to pump money into company so there is relative security that the company won't close for business,
cons: Management in fighting between those from former Houshold Bank (Chicago), Marine Midland (Buffalo), and New York. Complete disconnection between the 3 groups. NY attempts high brow advertising campaign looking to attract affluent individuals and commercial banking customers, while Buffalo targets Sabres fans with name recognition and branch saturation. Chicago taken over mortgage company after sub-prime mortgage business was halted and in run-off. Depew operation is being dismantled and relocated to former Household operation centers. Mortgage still flooded with tons of personnel no longer required for limited retail business. No longer requires huge staffs of PHD's running analytics and reams of reports, multiple layers of managements, highly compensated senior management staff comprised of Buffalo and Chicago individuals.

review_title: Good first job out of college, but not a career
job_title: Mortgage Lending Specialist in Buffalo, NY
pros: Their pay for performance structure does reward the top performing employees. There are a lot of opportunities to post for other positions. Opportunity to advance if you are liked.
cons:
Coaching and on-the-job training are lacking
Favoritism is apparent, especially in promotions
Performance goals led to micro-managing, with monthly meetings about performance which can start to get redundant 
Lot of turnover in management which changes goals often

review_title: Slow moving global bank with good benefits
pros:
- Good benefits - vacation policy, 401k, health. Remote work is allowed but highly dependent on area and immediate management team 
- Global bank, deep pockets, very low risk of going out of business
- Diversified business model and some ability to transfer across business lines
- Have brought external talent to shake things up. Early to assess impact.
cons:
- Behind the curve on adoption of technology, at least on the Retail Banking side
- Highly matrix'ed organization slows decision making and limits delegated authority 
- Not a place for an entrepreneurially minded individual 
- Growth opportunity exists but upward mobility limited as the company struggles with improving cost efficiency, i.e, slower promotions to director, SVP and above levels. 
- Needs to do a much better job of identifying and promoting talent  - acquisition is much harder than retention

job_title: Premier Relationship Manager in New York, NY
pros: Very diverse, international. You can meet talented people from different cultures and countries. Good benefit, pay is higher in banking industry. Big company and tons of opportunities to grow. You will be doing way more than your job description says, so you can learn and grow in a fast pace.
cons: Don't get too excited about the higher pay comparing to local banks. They may pay you like 1.5 person, but they will make you work as more like 2 or 3 people. You will constantly wear several hats. Currently under the tight budget control, overtime is almost not allowed. You will probably end up with losing personal life and not getting paid for overtime. When you decide to leave, you are over qualified for the same role in other banks and no one will pay you the same, you are doomed.

review_title: Summer Intern in Retail Banking & Wealth Management
pros:
Good brand name
Good networking opportunities
Decent retail banking experience
Great pay for interns 
Company benefits (gym, catering, prime London locations, compensated travel expenses)
cons:
Very limited wealth management experience
Very limited opportunities to make a difference
Highly simplistic task with the overall goal of showing "this is what a bank is", but your participation in the life of a bank is very limited (i.e. you don't do anything that provides decent value for bank)
Was assigned to work 4 weeks for charity activities, instead of proper 4 weeks of wealth management experience

pros: Learn all the tricks of operating a multi-regional / global organization.
cons: The redundancy procedure was as un-humane as one can imagine.   With decades of service in the organization and plausible appraisals, there has been no discussion whatsoever.  A lot of unconfirmed news hanging around, and on one morning, login to company intranet blocked, called by manager into a meeting room, handed the redundancy letter, access card confiscated, had 5 minutes to pack belongings and escorted down the main gate, never to be allowed entry again  It was as if I committed serious breach that required disciplinary action!  And never a chance to say farewell or celebrate the decades of efforts there.  What a humiliating experience, especially to end the decades long of service!

review_title: Untapped company potential due to frustrating employee policy
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Brand name recognition, location, fast-paced environment (many projects to work on)
cons: Management cares little about their staff, no willingness to retain talent within the company. Very little internal mobility. Recently on a downsizing trend. A lot of politics which is to be expected in a bank, but can refrain from moving, progressing both as an individual within the company and as a company on the whole.

pros: Great colleagues, world class training inputs, world class offices, world class benefits and growth opportunities
cons: matrix structure takes a while to adjust to, you need to network well to move up as its a large company and you need to be able to market yourself after you've done a good job

pros:
Good work Life Balance
Flexible work from home facility
Good Shift Allowances
Good carreer opportunities( Only if you push yourself to learn more, The company will promote your additional skills but they won't push you to do additional trainings)
Fair yearly increment ( above 10% on an avg)
cons:
No onsite opportunity
If you are lucky and got to travel to any location it will be of short duration ( 3 months max)
Meagre allownaces if you are on Onsite.
GLT Management is not Good.

review_title: go, get trained and then leave after 3 years.
pros:
Getting responsibility at an early opportunity.
They pay for your courses so you can find an exit 
The retail network....an amazing source of funds
Making excellent connections
cons: Happy to maintain a poor to mediocre image.  They never strive for excellence.  HSBC doesn't want to be seen to be risky as it has to protect its brand so it is happy chugging along the bottom.  Anybody who wants to look after the client by making sensible investments gets shot down pretty quickly.  There is no investment culture as proven by the lack of wrinkles and grey hair....they have all had enough and left.  On the flip side, if you can hide below the political parapet you will rise to the top.  The pay is pretty atrocious as they are not your clients, yet the management are surprised when people leave to other fund management houses to monetise their client relationships.

review_title: The balance between good and bad
pros:
1) Increment can range from 3% - 15%. As per work performance  , 
2) Bonus are generally good if you are performing well in the team 
3) Less manual work, mostly have been automated 
4) Career growth possibilities are aplenty
5) A lot of useful resources available on Intranet to equip one with knowledge
cons:
1) Management is too focused on cost cutting / saving   
2) Biasness towards staff from a certain region 
3) Staff benefits and policies are not standardised across regions /countries 
4) More benefits / recognition for staffs in UK 
5) Organization have a lot of values and practises in place (by the book), however do not see many are living up to it , which makes it pointless.

review_title: Nice workplace for interns (if you aren't looking for technical stuff)
job_title: Industrial Placement Trainee in Tseung Kwan O
pros:
- Friendly and caring seniors
- Nice working environment, with a huge garden and a gym room as well as a common room with massage chairs, table football and snooker
- Staff benefits such as 30% off discount at Pacific Coffee and low-priced Ocean Park tickets
- 1 day of work-from-home option per week
- Shuttle bus arrangement for colleagues living in Shatin/Taiwai, Tsing Yi/Tsuen Wan,  Mongkok, Admiralty, etc.
cons:
- Colleagues are constantly worried about the possibility of being fired, thus not motivated to work
- Conflicts between teams (within a department / between departments) can be complicated, mostly because of ambiguous team responsibilities
- Long travelling time to office: Located in Tseung Kwan O Industrial Estate, HSBC TKO Building is deep inside TKO, around 20-min walk distance from Lohas Park MTR station

review_title: On the whole, a very positive working experience
pros: I was given opportunities to work on various projects (training others, input into updating procedures, hosting meetings via the intranet etc), and worked my way up to 2nd line audit position. HSBC recognised my potential & expanded on it, which in turn aided my own personal & professional progression. For this, I am very appreciative.
cons: A downside to the above was that I would never have the benefits of permanent HSBC employees, as my contract was external (via a recruitment company; Reed Employment Agency); although I carried out the work of 'higher teams' (some of who I had even trained, to perform such roles, perfectly), and I shouldered much responsibility, I could never benefit the same, financially; I would always remain on much less wages.

job_title: Vice President -- Capital Financing in New York, NY
pros: Applicable only to the Capital Financing team in NY -- work with great people and hours are reasonable once you've reached VP title. 6% 401k match, 25 days vacation, cheap health insurance options with 90% coverage.
cons: Too much politics, run by London so you have to be British, base pay freeze for last 5 years even with promotion, they pay market value to newcomers but don't bump up pay for loyal current employees, lots of layers of people that make the org structure cumbersome and complex (reminds me of the government), not a meritocracy even if you increased p&l you won't get paid for it.

review_title: It is a place where I can grow not only professionally but intellectually and where training and education is available
pros: I would have all the necessary equipment i.e.: computer, scanner, fax and phone to do my job effectively. My schedule would be flexible and my work hours would be filled with productivity. I excel in an environment that has good communication skills and great teamwork but I enjoy working independently. My supervisor would be employee friendly with great communication skills and could coach and lead me to meet common and rewarding goals
cons:
Bankers tend to err on the side of caution. This conservatism may not appeal to many fresh MBAs who are looking for dynamic, business development kind of jobs right from day one.
They give you only a limited choice of final posting or function at the entry level

review_title: Market data team bangalore : worst set of people managing this team
pros: Good annual bonus and increments .nothing else. I don't have any other pros to say
cons:
Management is worst and not skilled to solve the issue. Here is the list of cons ..

1. Market data team is a sinking boat and the  managemental is trying there best to make it sink as soon as possible

2. Management have few favourite people in the team and they can bend to any limit to make there favourite employee happy.. This is making bad atmosphere in team and spoiling the team. 

3. Hiring is done not based on skill but based on who has referred and how close that employee is with management. Skill doesn't matter.. 

4. Too many escalation and issue.. its never ending story.

5. Too much work pressure

review_title: Great Business Aligned roles within IT.
pros: Great culture to work at. Employee friendly with access to managers to openly discuss about ongoing personal issues or stress scenarios arising out of work. Investment Banking Dept offers exposure to projects aligned to latest trends in investment banking from a regulatory, markets and quantitative analysis perspective. Great opportunities to travel for business purposes, enhances learning by means of business facing and trading desk interactions for requirements gathering.
cons: Some of the strategic tools (e.g. IM) used are built or configured from a global perspective, and may not meet the response requirements for a specific department. Such a change will need multiple rounds of evaluation globally and signoff, typically a longer change cycle. This introduces the usage of alternate ticketing tools, needing to maintain sync between ticketing in multiple systems for reasons of consistency.

pros:
1) lots of opportunity to learn and work on new technology
2) Good leave policies for employees
3) Onbording payscale is good nowadays
cons:
1)Lot of restructuring 
2)Too Many procedures ,from company perspective it is good af Bank but for employees it gets irritating
3) Annual hike depends on project/department growth , company performance is not relevant here. So make sure you land up in a project which make huge profit. Else even if you perform best you may be getting less pay compared to associate with low performance in other project.

review_title: HSBC follows other finanical services companies as they continue to trim jobs to focus on the bottomline.
job_title: Human Resources Manager  in New Castle, DE
pros: At the time I worked their HSBC paid people well for a job well done.  I also thought that the recent focus on employee engagement was the approach, and focused efforts not only production but also on the welfare of employees, which are the most important asset.   There was also a great group of people to work with.
cons: The new performance management system focuses on attaining a normative distribution and the focus is more on meeting the numbers of the distribution curve than the actual performance of the employee.  It also seems that the real focus on on taking away the great bonuses and merit increases.   It is called pay for performance but it seems to be don't pay for good performance.

pros:
I have worked with this country for more than 5 yrs now. Since my total experience spanned across multiple locations of HSBC.Hence, I have to give a second thought before marking down my Pros

The working culture of HSBC is totally different across multiple geographies. So starting with 
HSBC India - 
1. Working Culture - too good 
2. Work Life Balance - Awesome
3. COmpensation and Benefits - Always generous in benefits. But people with less salary always falls behind the curve.
4. Type of work - Not so challenging
cons:
HSBC India - 
1. Management - my view is against the management. All dirty politics 

HSBC UK - I don't think of any.

HSBC US - 
1. Management - I dont like the working style. 
2. Compensation/Benefits - Not so great. as per the market standards 
3. Work life/balance - Pathetic. They don't have policy for extra time 
5. Working culture - Too bad

pros: The division had very smart people. The work was at thesame time challenging and intellectually stimulating. I was given a lot of responsibility right out of college. The management was very competent and supportive of work life balance. Every work day was interesting in a different way with an excellent balance between quantitative and qualitative work. The office is especially nice with a great gym and break room equipped with pool, ping-pong, foosball and Direct TV satelitte on a 50 inch flat screen TV. I can't think of a better place to start your professional career. For a year I learned more than during four years in college.
cons: The company as a whole is too big and cumbersome. The most important decisions were made from Senior Management at the Headquarters that had no contact with the business operations. At times there were feeling of dissatisfaction of not knowing if your work is going to matter.

review_title: Let's have a meeting about a meeting.
pros: A good brand name. External employers think of it as a bastion of excellence.
cons:
It's a bureaucratic nightmare. 
People are over promoted. Far too many people at GCB4 and too many people at GCB3 who should be demoted and told to actually do some work.
There is no downside to not doing a good job. This company tolerates underperformance.
The turnover of good people is horrific. If they actually developed their top talent, they wouldn't be left with a bank that is riddled with people that have been there for 15 years plus and think they know EXACTLY how the place should work. They lack perspective.
Know this - the only thing management give a monkeys about is progressing their career. 
Don't tell HR anything you wouldn't tell the CEO to his face. They are his henchmen.

job_title: Compliance Officer in New York, NY
pros: There is opportunity for advancement.
cons: The opportunity for growth comes from the high turnover, poor management, and enormous organizational issues.  All of their leadership is over burdened and untrained in their charge.  Real-time training is almost non-existent. The culture change that was supposed to occur due to regulatory and integrity issues did not actually take place.  The only effort I saw towards a culture change was the video they showed upon intake.

review_title: HSBC - Good But a Long Way To Go To Be Great.
job_title: IT Team Leader in Sheffield, England
