pros: Flexible benefits are improving. Contributory pension scheme is going to improve hugely in 2008. But the non-contributory pension scheme is being stopped (but thats no surprise). Strong team ethic where employees tend to help other employees readily. Information sharing is done as a matter of course. Truly want to be best bank for customers.
cons:
Big focus on using offshore resources whether they are right for the particular IT project or task. It's just a numbers game to senior management so much so that some projects just have 10/20 offshore developers sat around doing nothing, but so they can hit the ratio targets.

Far too much red tape and paperwork. Not enough freedom given to employees to use initiative and do what is right rather than blindly following managements poorly thoughout strategy.

review_title: Learned a lot being surrounded by some of the most gifted colleagues
pros: Company is filled with smart and friendly colleagues. Many of them are ex-consultants and top recruits from leading companies. They are willing to wait for the right talent and pay good money to get them onboard. Can learn a lot from direct managers. Large scope of work gives good general management experience. In general, company has very good intention to treat it customers the way they would want their own grandmother to be treated. Very strong supporter of environmental causes.
cons: Strategy shifts drastically when CEO changes. Consensus driven culture leading lack of accountablity. Every small decisions have to float up to London. In order to "manage better from London", silos were created which made environment very difficult to get things accomplished. In the US, bank failed to creat a strong brand despite operation in the country for over 25 years.

review_title: OK if you're not in the US
pros: large company with lots of tentacles.  So large it won't get bought.  Good benefits.
cons: shipping jobs from US to India.  The company clearly has elements regretting their decision to invest in the US.  It seems that now they want to keep only a few choice bits and throw the rest out.  HSBC is well positioned for global growth, but employees in the US definitely feel like second class citizens.  Upper level management seems only focused on cutting costs and are willing to drive the employees into the ground to make that happen.  Management seems perfectly happy to let employees work long, unreasonable hours.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros:
If you want to be a lifer with little work, especially during the financial downturn, it was a great place to be.  Of course, until you get laid off that is.  
Severance package was generous, 60 day non working notice (no need to come to work, will continue to get paid) + a severance package depending on your level which is 6wks for non exempt to atleast 12 weeks for the Analyst to Manager level, gets better above that.
cons:
Terrible Pay, merit increases and bonuses...I was below the 25th percentile of my market data point and that was common among everyone I knew in the team including the bosses.  
More bosses than worker bees, very top heavy.  Needless to say, once you go out of the business unit, its even worse with SVPs and SEVPs for keeping the building lights on and keeping the seats warm.

pros:
Fun loving company. Lots of events.
Best company if you want money with no work.
Work life balance depends on project and manager.
Weekend working not encouraged by many managers.
Hikes and annual variable pay is good.
cons:
Techies - pls dont join hsbc. You will forget your technical skills if you stay here for a year.
Initial stage of projects is taken very lightly and in later stages everyone has to work extra hours.
Very less onsite opportunites. Visa gets rejected for software engineers as onsite allowance+salary total does not meet the UK government's minimum salary to survive. Onsite allowance not revised since 2007.
Technically very less work. Process and environments take up a lot time.
Lot of hierarchy which is not actually required.
There is no single point of contact who knows end to end of any project.
Contract to hire has spread its root because of hsbc group's CEO. Company does not care if any employee is willing to leave hsbc. He is immediately replaced by a contract employee.
Attrition rate is very high.

review_title: Opportunities to move up offset by discouraging climate and low pay
pros: If you put in time and express interest, there is opportunity to move up. Decent work/life balance. Core vacation of two weeks isn't too shabby (but it eats up all your vacation time). Some managers encourage you to learn and grow while others pass on ownership and micromanage.
cons: Lots of turnover in branch management and relationship bankers. The bank is trying to transition to attract premier clients, so anyone beneath that premier status is looked down upon, which is discouraging when it comes to customer service. Lots of employees cut corners and are somehow rewarded for it through extreme favoritism. Not enough hands-on training.

job_title: Customer Care Inbound Service Representative in Alabang
pros: They are not a typical call center environment. We can bring our personal belongings into the production area. We can bring food and pantry on the production floor. We can bring cell phones. Company events that they encourage everyone to join and shuts downs the site. They call it "Best place to work." They provide 25 VL: including SL, EL, B-day Leaves and required to plot 10 core leaves from the 25 as they practice work-life balance and additional 7 leaves for SOLO Parents as mandated by law and may use it even if you are still a probationary employee. Annual Profit Sharing even for those who are not yet regular employees.
cons: Very low basic salary. A very complex account that does not compensate the salary. Cannot cover unlimited HMO dependents, employees need to pay HMO taxes including the first 2 dependents.

review_title: Solid company with a strong direction, but management needs to be more thoroughly vetted.
job_title: Consultant for Technology and Services in Chicago, IL
pros: HSBC is a worldwide bank with a solid reputation.  If you get put under a good manager, you will be well taken care of and you can expect your career to accellerate.  HSBC is a solid company that you can expect to weather the storms.  Despite our exposure to sub prime lending, we have faired quite well in comparison to our competitors.
cons: Many of the managers are incompetant and if you are put under one of these people, your job will stagnate and you will hate your job.

review_title: Lots of potential if you're globally mobile
pros: There are some great benefits including generous 401k match and HSBC contributions to dependent care flexible spending account. If you are open to global opportunities, they are abundant - although most are offered "local terms" these days instead of a cush relo secondment. Depending on your function, there is a good chance you'll be able to work from home at least a couple days a week; there are also some 100% remote workers. HSBC also cultivates considerable diversity (including but not limited to racial and gender diversity), at least at the entry and middle levels. The top echelon continues to be male and white however.
cons: There are limited opportunities in the US since most businesses were sold (Cards) or are being run down (Consumer & Mortgage Lending). There has been major instability over the last few years with site closures, sales, outsourcing of certain functions, etc.

review_title: Make your own opportunities, but beware the constant change in priorities
pros: HSBC is so large and global, one can always find something interesting to do, and if not, it should be possible to build out your own opportunity. If you find an exploited pocket, go for it. Just know that it's unlikely that your efforts will gain you any status in the long run.
cons: The company lacks a strategy, except to "survive". This means means low risk appetite, poor internal investment, and conservatism & lack of drive. Management flits from plan to plan, leaving those under them to suffer consequences of constant turmoil. Employees should not expect any return (monetary or appreciation or otherwise) for their efforts.

pros: HSBC is a truly global organization with a presence in over 70 countries. It is a wonderfully diverse environment that melds the best and brightest from all cultures and sections of society. If you are willing to travel and embrace other cultures, HSBC can offer a hugely rewarding international career.
cons: As with many large organizations, it can sometimes feel cumbersome and bureaucratic. It can also be difficult to navigate to find the right people, information and resources. However, someone, somewhere within the organization is likely to be a world expert in the area you need. By conscientiously reaching out and building your network, and by utilizing the many internal 'social' tools available, this global talent pool is at your disposal to make you even more successful.

job_title: Senior Analyst Business Systems in Mettawa, IL
pros:
Flexible work hours/location
Company shows strong brand values and induction shows impetus towards image, consistency and ethics.
Relatively better compensation
Occasionally employees see a small gift on your desk from Leadership team thanking them for the hard work - Thoughtful of the leadership team.
Diversity - have not seen a place with wider diaspora of people, cultures.
People have flexibility to move laterally between teams
cons:
Lots of layers to accomplish tasks.
Project Induction is usually not well defined. 
Work life balance needs to be batter
Sr management looks at costs at the global level and want to keep North America thin at higher levels. That potentially puts growth at a slower pace

pros: They have global presence and support many causes.  The benefits package is quite good, one of the best in the industry.
cons: Managers take credit for your ideas and accomplishments, and the "little guy" never gets promoted.  Salary raises are either non-existent or laughable.  Meetings are the biggest downfall -- they take away from your work time, but you still have to do all your work, so you get to work like a horse.  Nobody recognizes your good, hard work. If you're friends with your manager or know how to brown-nose, you get all kinds of perks.

review_title: A company that truly invests in the employee
job_title: Assistant Vice President Project Manager II
pros: I worked for a demising division of HSBC, and having been a part of that culture with other employers in the same industry, I can say that HSBC has gone above and beyond to care for their employees. The provide just about every avenue I can think of to promote growth, work/life balance and philanthropy.  I would recommend them as an employer to anyone, at any time. Management is excellent and supports their employees to grow and succeed, and the benefits are top of the line.
cons: Even though they still have a corporate center in NY and a small retail banking presence, they no longer have a diversified presence in the US.   Unless you are able to work remote for a global position or relocate, positions are minimal.

pros: My coworkers are great and I could not ask for a better team to work with or to be a part of. When I started, we had a great culture and really embraced the growing start up vibe. On a team level we are there to help each other every step of the way.
cons:
Our comp plan was recently changed to the point where many of us cannot afford to leave. We are completely  under appreciated. Pay us less and expect us to do more? Not really a good way to run a business.
I would not recommend joining the company at this time. They are so focused on becoming public that they have lost their full sense of what HSBC is about.

pros:
I had joined HSBC at Hyderabad, Banjara Hills and it was a beautiful location to be in.........About the Co....the work environment there was just what any one would want from his /her workplace.

Best part of the Co was its retention policy & leave policy which are so employee centric
Elderly people who come to work are dealt with great patience and care so that they do not feel that they are less efficient..
cons:
Downsides of late have increased...it differs from location to location and surely the individuals who help the co grow are the ones who are responsible for its upliftment

Politics
Rating the individuals through a method which leaves them nowhere and demoralised
Lack of leadership qualities in the managers
Promotions have become a gimmick
honesty is severely dealt with
Unfair treatment
Policies are amended not for the benefit of employees but for the management may be....

pros: They offer decent work-life balance and vacation days
cons:
management that has no functional/technical skills in the area they are managing because they were hired by their friends in senior management. Nobody knows what they are doing and so things never really get done adequately. No investment in the career of their employees which is why they have a low employee-retention.   Management makes promises that never come to light unless it serves to benefit them more.   Likewise, career opportunities are only offered when they serve to benefit the management more than the employee. The good ones end up leaving once they realize what's really going on.
HR is almost nonexistent.  I have never met my HR rep (if i have one)  They do nothing to assist employees with HR-related issues.  Intact, any complaint to HR usually comes back to bite the employee

pros: Good environment to, but you must have luck to take a good manager. You can plan your carreer and there is a lot of trainning. There is a huge difference between the projects behaviour if it is a project for the front office or the back office.
cons: The HR lives in another world and do not expect more than 5% increase in your income. It's the determined roof! The processes are unconnected and it's common to find someone that will make really complicated simple things. It works with ancient technology and the HR have agreements between them to block you from going to another jobs. The HR process also can take very a long time to happen, and as result resources are lost to another companies.

pros:
Compensation is better than Service based companies
Good Training facilities
Good CSR Initiatives
Good Work-Life Balance
cons:
Management is worse and doesn't take care of employees feedback. Biasing is more prominent here. In the recent past, HSBC has lost its sheen with its new startegies towards employees. Attrition rate is too high. 
You will end up not having any growth if your team size is too big and manager gives you excuses every time you ask him/her.
Dont have proper support team and dev team ends up supporting projects.
Going to onsite is worst as you wont earn enough money and end up working 12-14 hours a day.
Onsite team is worst here. Very rude behavior towards offshore.

job_title: Human Resources Manager in London, England
pros:
great office environment 
good benefits (kind of)
innovative thinkers
well respected global brand
marketable to future employers
efforts towards global programs
cons:
awful management in HR
poor communication
lack of transparency
bad, not actually awful on boarding experience
poor pay
no recognition for delivery of work
expected to work incredibly long hours
old boys (and girls) club - not welcoming to new people

HSBC is an amazing brand, and externally it is seen as an amazing place to have on your resume, unfortunately in my experience is was entirely the opposite, the worst place I have ever worked for nearly every reason imaginable.  The only plus is that there are some amazing people there, skilled, talented, and professional but sadly they aren't words i'd use for any of the management staff in the HR team.

pros:
1. Believes in work life Balance
2. Salary comes before the end of the month
3. Bonus is paid out in shot
4. Has a good escalation system
5. Normally follows tried and tested methods in the bigger functions / processes but does try to encourage out of the box thinking
6. Comparatively good salary when comparing with Indian market
cons:
1. Follows the same method of out of the box thinking which is automation
2. Does not trust home working. So inspite of  having home arrangements is very hesitant  to allow it. The same is NOT true for UK / USA / Latin America / Dubai
3. In HDPI employees are treated slightly childishly hence there is a lot of singing & dancing competitions / floor decorations / no bags on the floor and no cell phones for many job roles and job grades.

review_title: A world-class bank with international opportunities for employees
pros:
Employees will have exposure to international opportunities, either through secondment or working with staff from other countries. 
IT department is well established that employees will be able to learn about standards, best practices as well as how a bank run.
Usually IT professionals such as developers, BAs and PMs will be working on projects from all sizes ranging from under a million to over 20 millions.
cons:
As the organization is large, the opportunities for promotion within one country bank or Software Department is limited as staff then to stay in a position for a long time.
Also, due to the complex working environment, there are a lot of procedures to follow for making even a small change.

job_title: Mortgage Service Specialist in Brandon, FL
pros: Recognition, incentives, All star, advancement within the company, staff events off site, week of service (giving back to the community), Open door policy
cons: Big high school, buddy system, Claims to have work/life balance but doesn't, company is big on technology when it comes to time off request (computer does not understand an emergency), upper management (most pretend to care), incentives ( says no cap but fixed so that no one can get past a certain number... calculation changes monthly based of production after the month has completed)

review_title: NOT A GOOD COMPANY TO WORK FOR ANYMORE
pros: GREAT EMPLOYEE BENEFIT, Sizeable company
cons: UNREASONABLE TARGETS, NO CAREER DEVELOPMENTS, LACK OF TRAININGS, NO WORK LIFE BALANCE, ESPECIALLY IN RETAIL DISTRIBUTION. MIDDLE -SENIOR MANAGEMENT WORK AGINST THE GROUP SENIOR MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES.

review_title: Trying to evolve but still not delivering on the promise of "the best place to work"
pros: Working for a member company of the largest enterprise in the world has the advantage of diversity at all levels, if you are willing to put in the hours and overperform there are great opportunities to advance, locally or internationally. The bank prides itself in being a meritocracy where merit is the basis for promotion, although perhaps not perfect they do try.
cons: A lot of red tape and a policy of salaries below the market average makes you think often that you'd be better off elsewhere. HSBC bought this bank less than 10 years ago and the culture is still mixed, so different people have very different opinion.  There are still many old practices and inefficiencies that don't correspond to a global bank, so you have to navigate carefully.

review_title: HSBC said acquiring Household Finance was "a mistake"
pros: HSBC is a global finance corporation with good profits in India and China.  In the U.S., they are losing money due to their sub-prime mortgage exposure.  Thus they are attempting to save costs by laying-off employees, which as a share-holder is the proper strategy.
cons: The headquarters are moving from London to Hong Kong, to take advantage of the China growth.  However, if you are working in the U.S., you are now an "ugly step-child" that headquarters is looking to save costs.  The former CEO was fired and a new CEO was sent from the U.K. to make cuts.  Thus employees are viewed as a cost and careers are an undue expense.  The survivors are wondering when the next cuts will be made.

review_title: HSBC Call Center is a revolving door!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Buffalo, NY
pros: They pay well and benefits are great. You are given a ton of time off that you earn as you go, but can take it after 90 days. There is overtime offered and a ton of people that can switch shifts if needed. There is a career progression in place (although it is broken)
cons: People are always getting fired. I quit because they were fast tracking new hires for promotions before the experienced workers. They keep changing your productivity goals to make it harder and harder to stay afloat. They tell you that you need to be trained on every product to move up, but it only makes it harder to make sales goals (which you can be fired for if you miss one of 4 or so stats three months in a row), then they promote others that have only been trained on a couple of products. Their systems are backwards and confusing to explain to customers.

review_title: Good at attracting talent, not so good at retaining
pros: Global company with an excellent brand and the recognition that goes with it. Ambitious in strategy and well positioned in emerging markets.Huge network and potential to leverage this network with clients.
cons:
Not very good at retaining talent as they just don't pay. Mediocrity is in the air and it is hard to differentiate yourself given the lack of reward and incentive culture. They call HSBC the civil service of the banking world.

The only people I saw rewarded were those who played the political game or threatened to leave the company.

Loyalty was not rewarded and nor hard work. HSBC is not a meritocracy.

review_title: Good Learning & Lucky Promotion, Very Bad Exit
pros: Low levels of work pressure, good facility, good environment
cons: Bad food, low levels of learning & exposure, very bad exit policies

review_title: Strong Brand, however no training program/employee support/bad IT/below-market pay
job_title: Premier Relationship Manager in North Vancouver, BC
pros: Great brand, some outstanding international and currency capabilities
cons: Job design is horrific (you just get swamped and are expected to somehow survive the first horror-show of 6-months to 1 year until you figure things out). No employee support, management believes negativity is somehow motivating (?), and IT/business processes are labyrinthine and antiquated. The entire company needs to be re-engineered from the ground up and most of the management and lifers canned.

pros:
Flexible work-life balance and the option to work remotely from home (for some department)
Health Benefits and 401k
cons:
Unprofessional managers - Some managers/senior managers need to learn about respect and take a good look in the mirror. Half the time people are leaving the company, and it's mainly because these managers are awful at their jobs.
Poor communication
Salary and bonuses

pros: Everyone I have met so far has offered their help and people are generally very happy to work here. I share in this view. The HR team are lovely, responsive, and always looking for ways to improve the experience for graduates. The social and work calendar over the first 2 months enabled all of the graduates to meet and build relationships with other graduates from all over the world, as well as senior stakeholders. Every step so far has also been an amazing learning experience, where I have been able to develop my technical capabilities while also building professional relationships.
cons: The onboarding is slow. A lot of software and hardware can take ages to receive access to. Certain training resources should have been made available earlier to allow a more fluid transition for later stages of training.

pros:
If your face fits, you will progress.
Most of the staff are young, so will make friends etc. Some staff been with the bank 10 plus years so a lot of knowledge and help around
cons: Salary is diabolical for what you do. Managers are unhelpful, rude and can just be nasty. No compromise with hours when your life takes unexpected turns. out of roughly 25 managers i had, 2 were nice. the rest were horrible. most staff cry everyday because of how horrible it is.  pretend to love customers but just want you to hit target. you are measured against all peers in the country on how well your targets are. Working 7 saturdays 1 off, back in for 7 again. no work life balance.rather than giving you bonuses they give you one extra day off per year. horrible company, wasted 3years.

pros: None really, other than if you are from Devon and want to work under someone from Devon who knows nothing about Banking or Financial Services but will teach you a lesson in management
cons: Plenty, too much bureaucracy, when I say too much believe me, depends what part of the bank you join though all parts are equally bad, bosses are old school, new folks that come in from big brands will admit over beer that they haven not seen a worse managed bank like HSBc. I will be careful about dedicating your career to HSBC. It will make you redundant for life as you will never learn anything and below average salary will keep you hooked on and wanting more but you will not get any increases. Big bosses take all the increase.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: HSBC provides great opportunities for learning, training and personal development.  They have extensive on-line training, special training centers and provide a great tuition reimbursement package.  Depending o the department, you may also be able to help the business grow - management actually listens to feedback from their staff.  Direct manager should hold weekly or bi-weekly one-on-one sessions with their staff to discuss any issues and keep communication open.
cons: Communication from management isn't always as clear and timely as it should be.  You will likely spend a portion of your time putting out fires that could have been prevented with timely communication from the management team.  Semi-annual and annual reviews could use improvement - they are often done in a vacuum by manager without employee input.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Officer in London, England
pros: I think the best thing of working at HSBC is that you learn the basics of sales and have the opportunity to build an iteresting network. The employee benefits is quite good as the benefits have been increased and you can choose what you need.
cons: Promotions are quite slow and the pace of the retail bank is such that there is little time for training, although a big effort is being made to change this. Also I think the basic salary  (pensionable salary) is very low compared the competitors and people is not necessarily rewarded even if is evident you are making more efforts than most.

review_title: Good place to work, but not much room for growth
pros: Nice friendly people; Work/life balance taken seriously; OK pay compared to other companies; Good Benefits; Excellent 401K with matching
cons: Some IT groups are badly managed; Promotions are rarely given and only to those that are manager's personal friends; Not sure about the future of the company in the US.  Changes technology direction too often, too many standard procedures, too much documentation - waste a  of time and money.

pros:
Best in class learning and supportive colleagues.

- Excellent and supportive colleagues

- Access to best in class learning

- Flexible working and work life balance promoted throughout the organisation
cons:
Politics makes career progression slow.

- Lack of meritocracy, often those with knowledge and understanding overlooked for positions of responsibility

- Low employee engagement and lack of appreciation from leaders

- Although work life balance is promoted, long hours are accepted norms

review_title: I would recommend this company to work for....the positives outweigh the negatives.
pros: One of the best reasons to work for this company is mobility.  HSBC is a global company that makes it a priority to encourage pursuit of a wide variety of opportunities in many different locations and disciplines.  Therefore, a lot of the employees stay with this company for many years due to the opportunity to keep things fresh by trying different things within the company thus creating a more well rounded employee.
cons: The downside of working for HSBC is the current market conditions as the majority of HSBC's North American operation deals with subprime lending which obviously is a risky area to be in right now.  Also, the talent and leadership of Senior Management can be more consistent.

review_title: Hit or miss depending on department or team.
pros: Safe company in tough times, despite what seems regular cut backs. Funding for staff development has not been cut back. Lots of opportunities as such a huge employer, just need to find the right area for you (something I have not achieved thus far). Generally a good overall culture.
cons: Very bad management in many areas. Development plans are encouraged within team, but then very rarely lead to promotion. Salary below market rate on average across group. Expenses constantly cut back for Shareholders and profits, but nothing seems to be re-invested in company. End of year rating system with set benchmarks for each grade is flawed.

pros: They pay was decent when compared to other banks.
cons:
High stress, little time off unless you count "core leave" which is a mandatory two weeks. 

Very political and highly silo mindset within all departments. This lead to projects being derived from group aka the UK and not within each regional market. 

Hard to understand how anything is run when it's so inefficiently. The bank can not even understand its own customers.

Advancement is very difficult unless you know somebody internally. 

Your manager will change a lot, they kept editing the functional and entity manager I had on what seemed to be a monthly basis.

HSBCnet is a joke and cash cow as clients must pay an astounding fee just to have online access. This is a systemic issue which will never be fixed and will continue to drive clients away.

review_title: Ideal for people who don't like to work much.
pros:
Some teams/departments have great technology - RBWM Digital, GBM, etc.
Some managers are understanding, and easily give WFH.
Most colleagues are supportive and approachable, same goes for most managers.
Leave system (25-30 privilege and 10 sick, 10 consecutive mandatory) is one of best in industry.
cons:
Low focus on tech (bank-first, tech-company-later approach).
Little to no focus on agile and devops.
If you begin to work well, you'll get burdened with the work of entire projects on your own.
Cumbersome approach for approvals for anything tech-related - ranging from a a few days to a few weeks.
Senior management have categorically stated that they will never let go of 'heritage' tech like mainframes - which means most tech of HSBC will be stuck in the 60s.
Few aspects like strict dress code, bad cafeteria food and bad seating management on floors needs to be improved quickly.

job_title: Senior Compliance Officer in Mettawa, IL
pros: Benefits and Time Off. Be careful work life balance and work from home are determined by the department head. I never experienced work from home and was told upon hiring it was a part of the corporate culture. Work life balance be prepared to tell your manager why you need time off, they decide if it is a good enough excuse.
cons: Department Management was stagnant. Wage increases and bonus were based on time with company, not on merit. Employees near retirement were protected and not required to produce. If you are LAZY and looking for a job and a paycheck this is the place. If you are ambitious, educated, want to be inspired or want to inspire others, I suggest you pass.

review_title: Opportunities for the lucky and determined
pros:
Global company with plenty of opportunity to diversify your career.
Willing to invest in your development.
cons:
Perhaps too big.  Top level management rhetoric doesn't necessarily translate to how people are managed on the front line.
Despite moving away from official 'targets' its very much about profit and you're only as good as your next sale.
Increasing (and necessary) regulation means there are more and more demands on front line staff.  Yet we've only seen staff reductions over recent years.  As above people are over-worked.

review_title: HR Manager - Campus Recruitment & University Relations
pros: The best place to work for anybody who aspires to be treated with respect and love. Employees with Mental Health concerns like Depression, Anxiety, PTSD, Stress are cared for with empathy and are not let go off or degraded or demoted instead encouraged  to continue to improve in health and be in a position to contribute to the growth of self and government.
cons: People who are not aware and part of the HSBC / HOST Culture for a reasonable time tend to negatively impact the experience of employees who mistake their negative approaches as the approach of the company.

review_title: The Management from Top needs to change
pros: HSBC as  a brand is excellent. Its written policies, procedures, and the 3 principles, Open, Dependable and Connected are excellent on paper.
cons:
Promotes Bullying as the very top people only prefer their own colour to progress.
The culture still reminds you of the dark times where ethnic minorities are discriminated based on their origins. Politically promote issues of gender equal pay and then discriminate against equal pay. White colleagues get away doing less work with good pay but ethnic Minorities are pressured to work long hours with less pay. Line managers authorise expense for an unlimited and unjustified reason for a favourite such as a white colleague but would refer to incorrect procedures to delay or not authorise expense claim for a non white colleague.
HR is useless as they do not have the power to respond to any genuine concerns as all line managers and the top heads are colleagues and support each other.

review_title: Good benefits and decent pay, but lack of opportunities in US as its operation is outsized by UK franchise
pros: Very good benefits in terms of vacation and 401K, but health benefit was considerably downgraded this year. It very rarely lays off workers. It is a "pro" for people who are looking for an easy place to make an easy salary and do not want to worry too much about being fired.
cons: Lack of excitement, lots of office politics and bureaucracies. Very poor office admin support staff. It is a nightmare to book a conf room, get a laptop for traveling, report a system access issue, etc. I guess part of the problem can be attributed to its pure large size. However it is explained, it is just painful. People from UK office are given more opportunities than others, which is demoralizing to US workers.

pros:
1. There is global people survey conducted each year and all staff has an opportunity to voice their anonymous feedback.
2. Single client which won't die for next 100 years. Still lot of work to be transferred to offshore
3. Excellent managed at business level which makes it profiting even in worst slowdowns
4. Located in city center. You can reach from any end of Pune
5. If you can speak, you can avoid work pressures
6. Good work life balance
7. Recently given interim salary hike to reduce attrition
8. Some of the departments has cutting edge technologies to work
cons:
1. You won't get much technical exposure if not an enthusiast
2. Onsites are of short durations
3. Have drinks with managers and you can get onsite without performance.
4. Production support work may take toll on your life

review_title: Excellent company to work for!! Great career opportunities and is dedicated in making their employees happy!
job_title: Reo Assistant in Hoosick Falls, NY
pros: I worked for HSBC for 9 years and was the best company by far, as they are dedicated in making their stakeholders and employees happy! Great benefits and room for growth. There is always opportunity to gain experience in several departments. It can be a centralized environment which gives employees confidence in executive decision making.
cons: In all the years I worked there I had never had a problem with another peer, but I am aware if there is a manager who treats their employees with disrespect and dishonesty, they do not get the proper discipline they deserve. Nothing gets done and can feel as if you cannot speak up for fear of possible retaliation.

review_title: Good long term employer spoiled by business practices
pros:
People tend to stay a long time here which shows that if you fit in and get on you can stay as long as you want (assuming your department isn't cut).
Lots of oppertunity to move within the organisation.
Consistently profitable, meaning I got a bonus every year.
Lots of working from home options in certain locations
cons:
Forced bell curve assessments meaning that your end of year rating can be adversely affected if in high performing area or have weak management who won't fight for you.
Constant negative press for various infractions.  This directly led to me leaving.
Pay tends to be lower than competitors.
Per the pros there are lots of people who have stuck around for a long time.  Some teams have lots of dead wood or are very stuck in their ways.

review_title: Has too many changes that employee can not even keep up..
job_title: Customer Service Manager in Amherst, NY
pros: -brand name, well known bank as International Bank
cons:
- Many changes internally, service charges, employee structure, program and systems for employee, etc,  changes too often. 
- Many unhappy employee inside, that most branchs have super high turnover 
  ----one. people quit because they are not happy 
  ----or two. head office will announce to resturcture very often.

review_title: Been a real learning experience regarding international banking
pros: Great pay compared to competitor banks in the area,  they offer decent benefits, 401k plan. They also offer  true global banking for international clients.
cons:
Computer systems really dated, no real international connection between hsbc branches in different countries unless you pay to use a software to do it for business banking.
 For staff it can be tough to help clients here in the U.S. who have opened their Accts overseas because we don't have access via computer systems to see their Accts.

review_title: Fast-Paced, need to know how to work around things
pros: Experience, Knowledgeable Seniors, Deliver, Diversity
cons: Salary, No work life balance, Deliver

pros:
- International financial services and Premier level of client work looks good on a resume.  
- You will get to speak to high net worth individuals
cons:
- Flip flop on high level decision making/structure and goals 
- Poor work environment
- Clients become very unhappy when HSBC does not follow through on what it promises to do
- Read the Yelp rating, they make it very clear that HSBC doesn't, as a general rule, care about their clients
- Management has a disconnect from the day to day
- Retail bank is very poorly organized internally and very hard to function in

job_title: Assistant Vice President Sales  in Birmingham, AL
pros: HSBC was a great place to work with many dedicated people until they closed their Auto Finance Division in August of 2008. Salary's were fair and you were given opportunity to advance if you were interested in relocating. The company encouraged community involment, sharing best practices, and developing new ideas.
cons: Being a London based bank it was decided to move the capital to emerging markets in order to increase returns. After the sub prime crises, the returns in emerging markets were worse than if they had decided to stay in the Auto Finance business in the US. Many good people lost their job. I recieved an email explaining the Auto division was closed. The severence package was poor for the sales department.

pros: As a company it is indeed the best place to work. Employee centric plocies and job security are the major strong reasons to continue with HSBC.
cons: Am supporting th North America region for the past 8.5 years and since HSBC has withdrawn most of it business from NA, there is no growth that can be foreseen. Have waited for almost 9 years but nothing ha happenned. Every individual needs growth and a proper pay package at the end of the year. This is the right time to move out for a better career. That is the sole reason for looking for a change to get out of this stagnant position.

review_title: Good company to join as a fresher in the industry
pros: The job flexibility depends on the team you are working and not the organization. The benefits are good with decent variable pay and hikes based on your performance. A lot of fun activities and events happen often at the campus. I would say it was a really good experience for me since I got the initial training on a few technologies and there was a lot of flexibility to learn new stuff while working.
cons:
The scariest part is layoffs happen sometimes and you see a lot of people panicking. 
There was no hike for most people during the layoff period.

pros:
Brand name, decent salary, flexible shifts(mostly).
Leave management is good.
cons:
Infrastructure in Business Bay, Pune is below par. Lack of parking spaces and also (believe it or not) lack of chairs on the floor.
Bureaucratic processes.

Lack of willingness to adopt cloud in some areas.
Working on outdated technologies.

People who have worked on outdated technologies continue to serve as Leads and seniors even on newer technologies. This doesnt make sense as they have no expertise on the new technology, yet they lead such projects purely on the basis of the 10 to 15 years they have spent in HSBC.

Most of the senior technical people here are ones who have spent more close to or more than 10 years here. And they are woefully unaware of how the technical world outside HSBC has evolved in the past couple of years.
Technologies in use outside HSBC for the past 3 years or so is considered the latest one here simply because they didnt know about it.

Spending more than a year here would erode whatever technical skills you have.

review_title: Some candid feedback on middle market banking
job_title: Business Relationship Manager in New York, NY
pros: Growth of company creates opportunities.  Seems to value results but does not seem to like dissent.
cons: Very conservative credit culture.  Senior management needs to have a better grip on the "nuts and bolts" of how the operation is run and how to improve it as there is much room for improvement.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Chicago, IL
pros:
If one is looking for an international company with potential opportunities overseas,HSBC is a good possible employer in upper level positions. HSBC does do a very good job at exposing their management group to a variety of training in groups of fellow employees from around the world. This enables an executive to gain great exposure to a diverse perspective and gain some valuable networking connections. 
HSBC has a very competitive compensation package and is a fairly good work life balance company.
cons:
Senior Management is not forthright. This place has a terrible culture. They have never been able to integrate  the  Household and Beneficial companies into one culture.
One must remember that if you are not Brit you will never run this Bank even in the US.  
HSBC is presently in a no growth mode.

review_title: I can't believe how bad it was
pros: Employees can work remotely, decent work-life balance, great location in midtown Manhattan, strong brand recognition of company
cons:
-weak work culture 
-low morale
-painfully slow and antiquated IT systems, laptops, enterprise software, etc
-limited exposure to cultural/racial diversity considering it's a global bank
-environment not conducive to professional networking 
-weak communication channels of company makes cross-functional collaboration extremely difficult
-little career progression
-embarrassing amount of bureaucracy (even considering that it's a global company)
-ever-changing work processes, practices and expectations (makes "success" really hard to define when there's no agreement on how to proceed in a work stream)
-lack of institutional knowledge by colleagues (because so many long-times employees leave)
-blatant show of favoritism
-questionable decisions made that may border on unethical
-strong practice of blame shifting between teams and even within teams
-frequent office relocation
-fear of having your job moved offshore

review_title: At HSBC, continuous change is the name of the game and if you want to suceed at HSBC, learn to play the HSBC game.
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
International presence provides for mobility for those who seek challenges worldwide.
Large corporate culture.
They are a well capitalized company that will survive the current economic climate.
HSBC looks down the road and plans for long term growth - not short term profits for the stock price.
cons:
Large Corporate culture.
Continuous change is the name of the game at HSBC.
An individual might spend 5 years in a position & are ready for the next level when their manager leaves.  
Unfortunately, at HSBC, international managers can be brought in.  The mobility at HSBC has an up and down side.
Evolving but does not deliver on " Best Place To Work".
Some policies are not thoroughly vetted and are somewhat impractical in the real world - " Clean Desk"

review_title: Great potential to grow your career if you start under the right management
job_title: IT Project Manager in London, England
pros: There are plenty of global opportunities at HSBC from the investment banking division to retail and private banking.  HSBC are a cash-rich bank that is well positioned to take advantage of the current economic climate - they have taken substantial losses but have a diverse ebough portfolio to have coped well with the last few years.   You will need to network hard but the rewards are there and there is a good medium for cross-functional communcations.  Plenty of annual leave and flexible working options. The investment banking division is condusive to raising a family unlike many other large US investment banks.
cons: old boys club in some area's - limited training and pro education opportunities

review_title: Although I was given the lattitude to do many different things professionally,  mgmt didn't give much credit 4 good work
job_title: Vice President & Director in Mettawa, IL
pros: Well respected and stable financial services company that is committed to being conservative in their approach to business going forward.
cons:
1) "Some" in the SVP and higher ranks talk the talk but don't necessarily action on it.  On a number of occassions I have observed executive tunnel vision to outstanding work by personnel and in other situations relatively little things receiving high praise and recognition.  Seems to be a place where favorites are played.
2) Not necessarily a good business partner.  In a true partnership a balance is found between 2 parties such that the resulting arrangement is mutually beneficial.  I have observed questionable actions by executive management that were intended to unfairly take advantage of a partner.

review_title: Good for latrals not good for freshers
pros:
1. Open culture
2. Can learn how to work with the global clients
3. Onsite opportunity but limited to 6 months most of the time and on rotaltional basis
4. Fun at work - you can strike work life balance as there is not much presuree from the client side (Internal client)
5. Good for laterals as projects come without much fuss and project monitoring is not required that much; good company to settle down
6. Good brand name
cons:
1. Most of the points posted in the other reviews
2. No good salary hike - basically appraisal system is not good; perception, good relation based appraisal
3. No good learnings -technical and others - which can help you switch
4. Not good for freshers as you wont learn much

pros: The company has a work from home program that helps an employee save on commuting expenses. In addition most managers are very flexible when it comes to taking time off in last minute situations.
cons: The company instituted two corporate policies that really changed the work environment. One is the use of a forced ranking system on employee reviews.An employee's rating often becomes a popularity contest, or the outcome of bargaining sessions amongst the managers. 10% of the workforce are ranked 'below average' regardless of performance, and managers can't tell you who are your peers and/or higher ranked coworkers. In addition they no longer share market data on compensation, which they freely did in the past. Year end reviews previously gave you a target salary along with a %age of where you stand, now they tell you to go find the market data salaries on your own.

review_title: Great training, minimal room for career growth or salary increase
job_title: Associate in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros: HSBC Electronic Data Processing Philippines offers a very intensive training. This will give you the necessary backbone needed for your Global Banking and Markets background. Employees are also exposed to multitudes of people, from different walks of life.
cons: They pay new grads more than those who have rendered their service longer (in the company, anyway). Internal hires are given very minimal increase, and fresh grads are often better paid than their more tenured counterparts. Sheltered fresh graduates may get culture-shock-ed with the types of people working there. Career growth depends on management; work appearance ranks higher compared to actual output.

review_title: Soul draining --- not for those looking for a balanced life
pros: Opportunity to work with colleagues around the world.  Great for those looking for diverse career paths.  Good benefits and plenty of vacation days.  Flexibility to work from home.
cons: Work-life balance is nonexistent.  Regular early/late conference calls (4am - 11pm, depending on which countries you're liaising with).  Highly bureaucratic and inefficient.  Restructures frequently.  Matrix reporting leading to increased workload and conflicting priorities and messages.  Targets usually set by upper management or UK headquarter without reality check with staff to determine what is reasonable.  No sick days (must use vacation days if sick).

review_title: To make an omelette you must first break some eggs.
pros:
Good knowledgable experienced co-workers with right mentality to succeed. 

Generally sensible working hours with a good working environment conducive for success.
cons:
Often tied up in red tape driven by well meaning but poorly executed interpretation of regulatory environment  which can lead to not being able or left alone to service clients in the right way.

The division I work in has a mission statement to put the client at the heart of everything we do but often that couldn't be further from the truth. 

A leadership regime that can't fathom how to deliver bottom line growth so makes difficult decisions and cuts resource to the bones should only expect one outcome - people to leave of their own accord and low morale from remaining employees.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in New Castle, DE
pros: Hands down, the people were the best feature of this job.  Everyone with whom I worked was professional and dedicated to the job.  The company itself offered competitive salaries with good benefits.  Work from home option was nice, as was the flexible schedule and tuition reimbursement perks.
cons: While my career advancement was not hindered in any way, it was also not strongly encouraged.  By that, I mean that management would not take an active role in propelling you forward.  It was left entirely up to you --  which, if you are unaware of opportunities or how your skills could best be utilized, you'd end up missing out on potential career advancement opportunities.

pros: Money is ok, Pension is better, Location is ok.
cons:
Management operate in a clique and target individuals. I saw them mistreat and ignore someone who left in a sideways move.
Also saw them not only refuse a annual pay increase to someone who was highly skilled, whilst asking them to continue with profile raising tasks... this meant people new in the business were getting paid more than them.


Assessors for work highly subjective, 1 assessor will have a different viewpoint to another, meaning you can fail your monthly targets due to subjectivity and it is a hard battle to get their decision over turned even if you have a strong case.

Shares - wouldnt bother with them as when you leave there is a sting in the tail.

review_title: Good place to work. Certain things might not attract people but overall a good place to work
pros:
- Culture
- Gives a sense of confidence to the associates when they feel associated to such a huge brand name.
- Good work-life balance
- Overall decent environment to work in
cons:
- HR not so efficient and responsive.
- Top management not too clear about the future plans their roles and responsibilities.
- Appraisal system not taken seriously.
- Some sort of bias treatment from management.
- Frequent changes in organization structure, leaving a lot of uncertainty among associates.
- Facilities given but you have to ask for (kind of request for it) and that too should undergo a lot of approvals.

review_title: Poor management skill in senior management
pros:
- good benefits (leave, medical claim, etc. )
- good relationship between senior and junior teammates
cons:
- Conservative HSBC culture inherit by line manager which migrate from bank to GLT tend not to be open to new ideas and approach.
- Strictly adherent to guidelines with little or no flexibility which set by line manager (e.g.. working hours)
- Salary not synchronised across departments, resulting in staff with same level of experience and/or performance but huge gap in salary range.
- Fresh grad salary (entry level) is almost the same with permanent staff salary (junior level approx. 2 years working experience in GLT) resulting in dissatisfaction among junior  co-workers

job_title: Consultant Business Systems in Vancouver, BC
pros: HSBC Bank Canada has solid long term employment and opportunities for advancement and changing roles, for people who want it. Bank staff have great work/life balance with flex time and good family days etc. The bank creates a profit and delivers its customers solid service. They have superior branding and market facing proposition. Bank staff are generally positive, friendly, interesting people.
cons: Like most banks it is very hierarchical and rigid in roles and responsibilities. The challenge with this is that there are few generalists and cross pollination of ideas. It also creates environment where things can fall through the gaps between roles. This is specifically relevant to the IT vs business dynamic.

pros:
- Decent number of annual leave
- Good international exposure - you will have plenty of opportunities to work with people in different regions
- Good mobility internally within the Group. If you want, you can move to other regions or even new business areas that you have never tried before. Hiring managers are generally willing consider candidates with slightly less relevant experience.
cons:
- Hours can be demanding sometimes especially when you are based in Hong Kong doing global roles due to the late night calls
- HSBC is too big as a bank and sometimes it can be hard to implement changes
- Because HSBC is such a big bank and all the roles and responsibilities are finely divided, you may become over specialised in certain areas which makes it hard for you to move out.

job_title: Premier Relationships Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good salary between-70k-80k, 25 day off , insurance Blue cross blue shield. 401k match 4%.
cons:
Horrible work environment 18 of the 20 branch managers are clueless. Almost every employee is afraid of losing there job for no apparent reason. Managers are afraid to make decisions on simple approvals. 
Horrible systems so outdated they constantly crash and they are developing new systems that are worse then the old. Horrible customer service can offer our customers simple service (can't issue debit cards at the branch it litterly takes 4 business days.
A revolving door with Premier advisors and Premier Banker. 
Commission suck discretionary bonus always at the low end

job_title: Head of User Experience & Corporate Digital Programmes in London, England
pros: The brand and global spread. Multiple business lines: Retail & Wealth Management; Private; Business; Global Banking & Markets. Massive investment in digital. Shallow reporting structure. Clear strategy.
cons: Lower than average employee engagement. Poor HR support.  Low balling on pay. Many admin functions devolved (e.g. HR, Procurement) with managers having to pick up the tasks. Big organisation that needs skill navigating and joining up. Business lines could be better joined up digitally.

review_title: watch for the next round of dis-intermediation
job_title: Senior Vice President in Salinas, CA
pros: international opportunities; however, don't expect HSBC to provide them unless you happen to be coming from the lowest cost nation for labor.  opportunities abound for those coming out of 3rd world countries to work as a secondee in a "center of excellence" country like the US.  however, US workers have few (if any) opportunities to work abroad.
cons: none.  it has lost it's direction and focus.  it is being micro managed by a bunch of old school, british bankers who will conduct a search for the guilty once their failed strategies implode.   a complete lack of ownership and accountability by the very people created the current malaise

review_title: Large multinational with lots of benefits, yet some important drawbacks
pros: The company offfers a competitive market salary plus perks such as monthly certificates for food, medicine, entertainment, etc; and discount for gyms. I found it an interesting workplace that promotes regional alignment of initiatives. I found it offers very reasonable work-life balance.
cons: Very traditional way of thinking (not outside-the-box). Leadership really depends on the local CEO's vision of business and management so it cascades to Heads and VPs. Quality of labor force goes along the same lines: in my own experience I was often disappointed at  the motivation and skill set of staff. High level of procedures and bureaucracy.

review_title: Good Company. Learning depends on Project
pros:
I worked for HSBC for 2 Years. 

1. You will get enough time to learn things
2. If you are into right project you can enjoy learning
3. Yearly bonus and Fashion parade you cant miss it
4. No pressure no deadlines
cons:
1. Because of Bank compliance issues HSBC is paying huge penalties to US govt hence facing crisis.
2. There is Pune vs Hyderabad culture
3. You should be loyal to your local management. If you are loyal to U.K based manager your Hikes and Bonus will be affected. But irony is you will be working more with UK couterparts and reporting to local manager.

review_title: HSBC is poorly managed and in disarray
job_title: Senior Collections Specialist in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Good compensation, many advancement opportunities, does alot for the environment
cons: Poor communication from management, no true corporate vision-only 'vision statments', horrible communication to employees, constant change interpretations of work flexibility programs makes planning personal life near impossible, every employee I work with feels they are 1 mistake from being fired, I am a top performer yet I am always made to feel I have failed, feedback is encouraged but often punished when not in step with management decisions, frequently terminates employees when they have a disability or major life crisis, lack of management accountability

pros: Great company that is creating inroads in the Asian Markets.  If you would like short term international assignments, this mught be a great company to explore.  HSBC is trying to grow the banking business in the US, card business is a drag - but that have put a strong front, growing the private label and parts of the subprime business.  Working in those areas will be fun.  Strong encouragement of work life balance, remote work etc.
cons: Strong Asian community in the Risk Department in cards.  One risk manager managing the Union and General Motors portfolio has bad rep with high turnover.  Try to avoid him if you can. In general very hiearchial organization.  Tons of bureaucracy - getting a computer could take couple of months.

pros: Being a global company has some great perks, none greater than deep pockets. Even though North America has been hemorrhaging, emerging markets have kept the company going.
cons: There are no growth opportunities unless you are willing to check in your integrity at the door. Performance uses forced rankings and HR in its infinite wisdom decided that a team of 10 can only have 2 good performers so regardless of actual accomplishments, they are rated low. Promotions, bonuses and raises are based on rating, which is good in theory but in this case just goes to brown nosers.

job_title: Senior Software Developer in Birmingham, England
pros: Good salary, good bonuses and the physical environment is good. There is a significant element of ongoing "on the job" training
cons: The appraisal system in place actively discourages people from working as a team. During the 3 years I worked for them it was unusual for anyone to help anyone out because if someone else had a problem it meant that they were likely to get a poor appraisal. The more and bigger problems other people had the better your chances of bigger pay and bonuses.  The fact that you were essentially isolated from people you worked with means that any team player will find themselves out on a limb.

review_title: Good Company if you get good Project
pros:
1) Good Salary if you are Lateral.
2) Work Life Balance
3) Office parties are quite often
4) Can Learn Banking domain
cons:
1) Managers are partial and don't know any thing technical. They are supposed to do only functional things at times.
2) Lots of politics due to bad rating policy. They call it (70 20 10) policy.
3) If you don't get a good project then company change is the only option.
4) Too much manager driven, HR play no role.
5) Very difficult to change project, most IJP's are fake. Its easy to change a company.
6) Most people are here for enjoyment & knows very little technical things.
7) Hires from any engineering college , need smart & techy people.
8) No Bench.
9) Little on site opportunities.

job_title: HDPI Credit Services Executive in Calcutta
pros: Beautiful office, good atmosphere and pick up drop facility available.
cons: Management of Kolkata karunamoyee ofc is worst. They are best to give u long long advices, but practically they are totally failed to support employees and recognise their hard work. Working here for last 10 years,  inspite of good performance, growth is 0 coz oiling is mandatory here. Data processing team's management is worst. They literally ragging me mentaly for last 3/4 years. Due to lack of career opportunity we are bound to work here for years after years. If you r expert in oiling then you will get promotion easily, but if cant they be ready to suffer like me. This mental suffering not only professional life, it afffects personal life and health badly.

job_title: Mortgage Servicing Ops Representative in Brandon, FL
pros: I worked for  HSBC Mortgage Services for 11 years in various departments.  Overall, good company. When I started in 2005, we got lots of perks, but due to the downsizing of the Mortgage Division, those perks disappeared.  I worked with a great bunch of people.  Yes, some were not that great, but that's at every company.  Loved the casual dress code.  From June 1st to Sept 1st, you could wear shorts and flip flops.  Lots of opportunities to volunteer in the community.
cons: They are selling off their some of the Mortgage Division, so lots of people are getting laid off. This has been going on for the last several years.  Credit cards were sold to Capital One.  No Mortgage servicing job opportunities.

pros: Work culture is encouraging, with good balance of individual contributions and sense of teamwork. People freely collaborate to address projects, action plans, etc. feel I add value every day. Management is forthcoming with information and provides regular feedback. I would continue to work here if possible (position ending due to wide scale layoffs).
cons: Feel like the global corporation side does not want us, makes us feel like we bleeding them out. Although they also say we are servicing customers ethically and we have a lot more documentation and processes in place than the global side, it still feels like back-handed compliment

review_title: At least this bank won't fail
pros: HSBC has a tremendously diverse culture and allows employees the opportunity to travel around the world.  There is much security in such a global and diverse company.  HSBC promotes upward mobility and recommends new jobs every few years.  This allows for a great overall understanding of such a large company.
cons: HSBC has an extremely conservative culture when compared to other large U.S. financial institutions. But hey, maybe thats why they haven't tanked yet. Right now the processes are inefficient and are in major need of automation.  I would say that overall, processes are 75% manual and 25% automated.  From speaking with employees who have worked at other large banks, HSBC is behind.

review_title: Only work here if you can hold your tongue.
pros: HSBC has started a work from home program, which is very generous and a good morale builder.
cons: This is a very hierarchal company.  There are so many gatekeepers and senior management expects you to be intimidated.  In many cases, managers are in the position they are not due to their skill set, rather because they've been with the company for 20+ years.  Poor management is not addressed.  Many employees are non-degreed and thus intimidated into believing they can't do better anywhere else, so they all just "drink the Kool-Aid" and don't ask questions or rock the boat.

review_title: Starting your career from HSBC may not be ideal, but retirement may be a good
pros: compensation, perks and promotion (depends on the business you are working on) are okay type. Please keep in mind, since its financial sector, so you should not expect much as IT person (may be core engineering, ITO, Analytic etc)
cons: You would get multiple promotion and big big designation (by name) here. But actually you need to struggle (for searching job outside HSBC) a lot to match similar designation (outside HSBC) and skill sets you have developed (inside HSBC).....huge difference. You may need to compromise your job satisfaction with compensation you would be getting in HSBC

review_title: You get used to the idea of complacency, knowing that you won't be advancing or changing roles for a very long time.
pros:
Office culture was great, the team I worked with was what made the job.
Training was absolutely unnecessary, you would have to sit through a week long course, 8 hours a day, which doesn't provide any real work experience at all. Just seemed to be filler.
Benefits are standard, standard medical, dental, vision etc... Vacation was the standard
cons: Depew, NY can suffer from snow storms, which leads to horrible road conditions. Upper management would say that you have to travel through the storm as the business is still open, even though the roads there were closed. Complete disregard of safety.

job_title: Senior Account Manager, Commercial Banking in Edmonton, AB
pros: good experience, good benefits, worked with some really good people, you can get promoted if you stay long enough or outlast your piers
cons: Middle manager are afraid of senior management, threats of making career limiting moves run rampant.  Management seldom ask are we supporting you is there anything we can help you to do your job better.  The culture doesn't make you want to do a good job, work life balance does not exist.  The variable income is the worst I have ever seen I was a top over performing individual in my division and regularly got a lower variable pay than a colleague that consistently did not achieve his revenue or other financial metric targets

review_title: Great people, shame about the 'historic' managers that run the Branches
pros: People, some of the training (depending on area), nice uniform
cons: People treated like dirt in branches, promotions based on looks, paid unfairly if promoted internally, managers expensing lunches and drinks whilst staff on rubbish wages.

pros:
Great work life balance for IT positions
A lot of great people to work with
cons:
Company has been slowly shifting resources offshore more and more. VERY little room for advancement, management does not recognize technical skills as they put a flat $$/hour cost on everything and offshore is cheaper regardless of skill level.
Don't expect more than a 2-3 pay increase IF there is even one for the year.
You are NOT rated for your performance but pitted against co-workers as they rate on a 70-20-10 scale. Every year 10% WILL be rated as poor performers regardless if your whole team does excellent work.

pros:
Good job, good people below senior management level.
Clear individual objectives for you to achieve.
Ability to develop in role.
cons:
No clear department direction, often feels like they just make it up on the fly.
Management are frankly not honesty about anything, I've met only two manager who have been and it was refreshing.
Always cutting jobs but not workload.
Whilst you can develop, there is no recognition for this and people take their skills with them.
All management act on short term selfishness, which often leads to poor management.
Often pay contractors and new staff more which leads to valuable experience leaving and not being replaced.
Too many graduates who know absolutely nothing but climb up the ladder and then leave.
Too many project manages who don't deliver whole projects.

review_title: HSBC - Overall Good With a Few Flaws
pros: Great benefits.  They are really serious about the work/life balance initiative; allowing several to work from home up to 5 days a week.  The organization at the most Sr. levels is very communicative.  You can see the vision and the strategy they want to see in place as they focus on the emerging markets.
cons: If you are in IT, management at the middle level is inept.  The wrong people are being promoted.  It's more based on who you know and less on real potential.  You have to fend for yourself which is exhausting and tiresome.  The squeaky wheel gets the grease.  Diversity is paid lip service at the Director level and above.

review_title: great for global career opportunities, but bureaucratic management system gets frustrating
pros:
- great opportunities to live and work abroad (global network = global opportunities)
- prestige of working for the world's largest bank (especially if you keep in mind they're way bigger abroad than in the U.S.)
- good at attracting above-average talent
- good benefits
cons:
- large number of employees means you sometimes get lost as just another number (often times no strong sense of community beyond work group)
- seemed a little stingy on the salary side of things, especially with regard to certain positions
- extensive management hierarchy means a lot of red tape and sometimes few opportunities to get noticed/move up

pros: Good work environment. Higher management is very approachable and understanding. Plenty of opportunities for working in different countries, even for new employees. You get a premium account with the HSBC bank which is really nice. Very good training programs for employees, some them are really advanced. Office space is excellent, loved the events and parties.
cons: Employees using niche technologies have extremely monotonous work and less scope of advancement. Lower management is prone to taking bad decision. Commuting options are bad, especially for employees working odd shifts. Too many processes to follow to the point you spend more time following processes than doing your work. Many of them are practically useless.

job_title: Unix Applications Support Analyst in Curitiba
pros:
Good work-life balance, flat hierarchies, excellent training programmes , excellent work environment located in Curitiba downtown, free coffee, decompression room, free quick massage, generous meal tickets.

They are very welcoming for freshers and internships, as long as you can speak a decent level of English. In fact, they are more interested in a good English level than your technical skills.

If you know basic SQL, Linux/Unix and Java, as well a decent level of English, you can probably find a job there.
cons: Not so challenging projects, so if you are a hardcore geeky person looking for technical challenges and "really cool" projects, it's probably not a good place to go.

job_title: Mortgage Servicing Specialist in Depew, NY
pros:
Hours can sometimes be flexible based on your department
Great people to work with
Potential to move up quickly with hard work
cons:
The fact that PHH is taking over most of this company in Buffalo has morale at a pretty low level. Future positions are unsure, along with some other disappointments, but from what I can tell they are mostly problems from PHH's side.
A lot of temporary workers right now means there can be frustrations dealing with high-turnover departments not fully knowing what they're doing. Again, it's just the situation the company's in and not much they can do about it.
Every second of your day is managed by a company system to calculate productivity- better not daydream too much

review_title: Good opportunities to move around different business areas and countries
pros: Whilst salary can be lower than comparable jobs in industry, the total reward package including pension and share options make this better than other companies. Once you are in the organisation it is possible to gain exposure if differing business areas and also take on secondments and transfers to other countries. Excellent place to work for young families due to flexibility with working hours and maternity/return to work options.
cons: As with any business of this size and considering the climate and strategy, job security can not be guaranteed. There are annual issues across teams when forcing a bell curve to rank individuals. This is meant to be changing but can't see it shifting to a complete revamp of the mid-year and annual review cycle.

review_title: HSBC North America thrives in an environment of bullying and harassment
pros: If you work in the right department, this can be a good company to work for.  Those departments are far and few between these days, despite multiple rounds of culture training.
cons: Consistent harassment and bullying are rampant.  For some reason those individuals continue to rise within departments and continues to foster a clique of favorites and create hostile work environments for those on the outside of their inner circle.  Continued harassment when brought up to superiors only results in the need for the victim to do more work to cover themselves and prevent any possibility for the harasser to complain.  This eventually leads to poor performance due to stress and work is delayed due to the additional levels of work to cover themselves and ability to obtain a collaborative work atmosphere.

Huge bank and highly bureaucractic
Clunky, frustrating and arguably obstructive processes
Shockingly poor systems and technology - no single sign-on, etc. 
Pockets of tough aggression and lip service paid to engaging and caring about employees (e.g. showing my vulnerability by declaring anxiety and stress ultimately led to my demise)
Poor people managers in leadership positions

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Hamilton, Scotland
pros: Nice people in your team.
cons: Hsbc is very much a face fits culture, you can only develop your career if you're manager likes you regardless of how good you are at your job. Hsbc is supposedly "customer centric" but all they care about is sales and profits. Even though they say there are no targets, if you're not selling they pile on the pressure to sell sell sell and threaten you with no bonus, no pay rise, and unacceptable behaviours! Customers are unhappy, customer facing staff are unhappy, big bosses are earning big bonuses and do not care for their staff or customers, you are nothing but a number to them....horrible atmosphere to work in! Unsociable shifts, regimented breaks and no recognition for good old fashioned customer service. Systems dont work, procedures are not customer friendly and out of date and complaints are justified.

review_title: Basically good, I would work there again.
job_title: Collector III (Call Centers In VA Beach and Chesapeake) in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Benefits are outstanding, middle management is decent, training can be very thorough at the basic levels
cons: Senior management could care less about the workers and pass the buck to middle management, who do the best they can.  No room for advancement because the wrong people are promoted, not for management/leadership abilities but because their production numbers were strong and they have friends in higher places.  Stability is lacking, lots of layoffs, no real idea of what's going on or why (for lower/middle management).

review_title: Overall, well managed, very service and goal oriented.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Albany, NY
pros: Train employees well all the way up the line, so that supervisors can keep training as you need to learn more things. Good benefits, good time off, good schedule (for parttime),
cons:
minimal raises. your beginning rate doesn't seem to increase but by 10cents... 
as with all banks probably, time off has to go on a rotation because there has to be so many people working at a time. need to have a solid person in charge of scheduling.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Buffalo, NY
pros:
Good amount of time off
Benefits avaiale for part time workers
Closed major holidays
Generous Tuition policy
cons: Each branch is different.  Some do not have a lot of work/life balance and some do.  New hires sometimes make more money than those who have been around awhile.  Employees are told no raise but some secretly get them-most do not.  Everyone in the branch who is not on the teller line thinks they are in charge of the tellers which makes for a divided workplace.  Sales are VERY important. Without them no raises and no advancment.

review_title: Fantastic potential for growth and mobility but you're constantly hindered by cost pressure and bureaucracy
pros:
Unparalleled global network and opportunity
Supportive senior management
Friendly and multicultural work environment
Good work life balance (if you want it)
cons:
High levels of bureaucracy
Excessively cautious management and processes 
Myopic focus on cost
