HR policies not well suited for talent retention
Time dependent approach to promotion (not meritocratic)

pros: I was treated well in this company but then it depends on the manager and the team leader you are reporting to. Some of them are good but some lack people management skills. I remember when I was working under this lady team leader she used to treat me very badly & used to shout for silly things. Once in a meeting I gave her a piece of my mind and team members were thrilled to see that since they were not able to do that. However, there was no negative impact and I felt happy that I spoke my mind out. She eventually quit and joined elsewhere.
cons: But sometimes if your team leader is not good enough you will have to bear the brunt.

job_title: Premier Relationship Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good pay and good work life balance. Upper level management are knowledgable and very helpful on your career growth (no much opportunity to move up though)
cons: A lot of long time employees are out dated of current banking technologies, operational norms, moreover a sense of customer service. This giant company is undergoing a culture change program that is moving very slowly, probably can't make it to the goal before it closes. Customers are pushing away by very rude branch service that rarely be seen in banking industry. All customer calling are routed to India that can easily put you on hold for an hour. Business is shrinking and branches are closing everywhere.

review_title: Digital - Not what it says on the tin!
pros:
- Amazing supportive colleagues 
- Great office with great facilities
- Good perks
cons:
- Tightly knit senior management team who are disengaged with lower level employees
- PAY PAY PAY! Not only is pay MUCH lower than the industry but there are huge pay differences between employees doing the same jobs
- False promises, all too common 'Things will get better soon'
- Extremely slow promotions and any hopes can be slashed if you have 'constructive feedback'
- A feedback system which is flawed - any constructive/bad feedback without evidence is accepted 
- Favoritism and a very gossipy culture

pros: good work environment, different  people from different ages, different backgrounds, sometimes you would get a chance to interact with other country people from offshore, gender diversity - male, female balance work force, different kinds of activities, challenging work mostly meeting targets at the same time maintaining quality, fast paced environment, good employee welfare ( i.e, nice facilities for employees which motivates to work, comfortable environment, good, comfortable washrooms, air conditioned environment), constant changing of process i.e., banking back end operations will be updating according to new updates, advancements, technology like A.I, block chain, etc.
cons: Growth is saturated, limited salary hikes, pay-scale below than average national income, less job security (layoffs will happen depending upon work requirement)

review_title: Probably the worst bank to work for in Canada
pros: They have newer and larger offices than other retail banks.
cons: Extra long hours, but no overtime pay.  There's no technical support based in North America, and their platform is always crashing. You have to to go work assuming that at some point during the day, you will not have access to your computer. They're not well established and simple things that would take  BMO or TD a couple of days to process (PLOC, mortgage, credit card, etc.), take HSBC weeks.  You can't even transfer registered plans without causing the system and your managers a spasm.

review_title: The best coworkers around complemented with ever increasing goals minimum raises/promotions (if any).
pros: HSBC is a fantastic place to work, as most of your coworkers are friendly and willing to help each other out.  Always looked forward to going to work.  Also you get the best benefits package around (health insurance, 401K matching, etc).  Large bank with global presence (well known).
cons: HSBC wants to compete with other well known banks who lead in wealth management, causing the goals to increase considerably, across all the staff.  Too much overhaul in UK, causing a trickling down effect here in the US.

review_title: Large organization that means well but doesn't execute very well
pros: The benefits are good. If your manager likes you, you can go pretty far.
cons: It can be hard for your voice to be heard in such a large organization. Often feels like senior management has no idea what is going on on the front lines. Bank politics often plays a big decision in projects, etc. Some management refuses to talk to others 'not on their level'.

review_title: Stable, flexible working but not as rewarding as it should be.
pros:
- flexible working, able to work from home once if not twice a week. Able to buy & sell holiday entitlement.
- good pension scheme
- relaxed working environment
- less redundancies than other banks
- most colleagues tend to be friendly
cons:
- career progression can be extremely difficult, hard workers don't seem to be rewarded accordingly. Much a case of 'who's best friends with the boss'.
- bonuses around 8-10% for above average yearly performance.
- payrises can be paltry some years (try £100 annual payrise!)
- training has been an issue, external training budget non existent
- senior management don't seem to care too much about those who actually do the work

review_title: Regulatory, compliance and market pressures sap employee engagement.
pros: Bank of Bermuda (HSBC Bermuda) is an excellent place to gain experience working with a global organisation. Being globally networked, with the right skills and talents, a professional can enjoy postings world-wide and be part of the tremendous commercial growth in the emerging economies.
cons: Without the right skill set and in developed countries, HSBC is not a fun place to work. Lay-offs, redundancies, a top-down command and control governance model and antiquated performance management make HSBC a very difficult place to engage employees and develop a career.

review_title: HSBC New York City headquarters,  Vice President
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Good firm to begin career in finance at NY City location. Several opportunities to move around the firm offer options to learn industry for newbies.
cons: Not a good firm for extended career growth. Poor management due largely to high staff turnover and poor ( non-existent) salary increases. No written policy explaining bonus structure,  and very poor health benefits and work/life balance.

pros:
Ability to work remotely for some roles. There are a few nice people.
If you begin in the GDP program and are located in NYC, there seems to be some great opportunities.
cons:
The company basically runs on a caste system and relies on the Trickle Down theory- you can have a stellar review and still not see an increase in pay (not even the small standard variety to account for the yearly increase in cost of living or as SOME sort of incentive to stay with the company). 

The systems they use are terrible- archaic, unreliable, and, many times, counterintuitive.

People who work in different departments and areas act as though they work for a different company which makes communication difficult and getting many things done tiresome if not impossible.

review_title: Worst HR process on this planet.
pros: I have nothing to say about it. HSBC HR policy never gave me this opportunity to do so.
cons:
I have never seen any worst HSBC HR process on this planet. I gave Interview in October 2016 and had Skype call with Project Manager. 
Also submitted all my relevant documents for my employment with HSBC but since then HR never called me to tell me even about the position for which I was recruited. I have been doing follow-ups with HR but they reply. They always tell they need some kind of approvals and their HR process to recruite new folks. 
Only God knows how they recruite other folks. 

Finally I surrender myself as I was not getting any reply from HR my hope is lost and finally joined another MNC. 

Thanks to HSBC HR policy to relealizing that in world there is one thing is worst than worst. That is HSBC HR policy. I decided I would rather sit idle rather then giving interview in my future.

job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Learned a great deal about listed derivatives (futures and options), trade life cycle, got to collaborate with some talented and knowledgeable people. Core leave policy was also a nice excuse to take a 2 week vacation.
cons: Poor management of their human capital, unwillingness to add headcount where it was urgently needed, increase in workload and decrease in bonus with no raises for 3 straight years, so essentially I was taking on more work and responsibility for less pay. On top of that, they were not willing to support my career aspirations (project management training) since it did not directly relate to futures. Got a taste of what it was like to be in a dictatorial regime.

review_title: Confused Org !! Company yet to decide they are working as bank or Software firm
pros:
Very social atmosphere. Every one discuss every thing other then work. Very enjoying and fun loving crowd!!
No pressure of following org specific process.
Good onsite opportunities if you are at good terms with managers. You can also look for permanent transfers to other locations like Canada and UK.
cons:
Impossible to switch the technology. Same thing for years will come in your way.
Impossible to change the project. Going to spend full employment under same manager. If you ask for change, your year end rating is gone.
Appraisal system is useless. Manager will bluntly talk nonsense and say do what ever you want to do, you will get this only. No evaluation system. All on personal preference.

pros:
BIG company, lots to learn from as everything is structure and so well developed. Systems are ok, pretty old but still not very inefficient. Management are open-minded but conservative when it comes to making real changes. 
- work life balance is for sure....OT is not encouraged ...
- values are nice, people are all good natured.
- culture is a bit mundane, people like to do their own part of work and thats it.
- lot of opportunities for internal transfer from front to middle to back in all business comparatively to other banks....
cons:
-status quo is deep rooted.
- too many people in org chart, overlapp of work, people pushing work around and adding layers in approvals....
- managers dont make approvals,
- too much people stayed too long here with not much contribution.....

review_title: Generally one of the better banks to work for
pros:
- Looking to grow and develop the business in all areas which means adopting new technology and ideas
- A true global presence
- A commitment to always be better especially considering its financial crime breaches of the past
- Good development of people through training
- Good career prospects even at lateral movements
- Depending on which dept you work for, great work life balance with up to 2 days working from home (depending on the location you work).
cons:
- Pay is often below market
- bonus structure varies across the business. Some get 25%. Some get 2%. No pay increase over last two years
- Structure changes occur every 3 or so years which result in redundancy and instability

review_title: Hostile culture due to lack of department funding
job_title: Bereavement Support Officer in Sheffield, England
pros: Central location, paid training provided
cons: This department needs more funding. Staff is overworked and stressed out. Team leaders are overworked and not available for help due to high stress. Hostile environment to newcomers and experienced workers alike. Bereaved customers are often unhappy with the lack of sensitivity and hoops they have to jump through to settle their dead loved ones' accounts. Due to strict policies and high employee turnover, the office culture lacks empathy, and sensitivity despite the department's goals centering around compassion. More funding and an expansion in staff count could be beneficial. Also, poor communication with other HSBC departments leads to unnecessary red tape and preventable mistakes.

review_title: A nice place to be working at.
job_title: Consultant Project Manager in Mettawa, IL
pros:
- Global exposure. Working with teams across multiple sites and geographies.
- Strong captive technology unit and committed to growth of in-house processing 
- Globally spread business; greater resilience to downturns in one country
- Strong and committed Senior Management setting clear visions and goals
- Wide availability of opportunities locally and globally
cons:
- Change, change, change
- Constant battle / challenge between local autonomy and 'group' priorities
- Benefits shrinking continuously in past 5 years

review_title: Large bank with very little innovation
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: They do not expect their employees to work as hard as other IB. The pace is more similar to a retail bank. If you are smart it is easy to shine. It is a global company, so you'll get exposed more to how other countries do business. They strive to put in global system and process, which has its cost and benefit.
cons: They do not attract the best talent. Most senior positions are held by British, including many US positions. They have international managers whom they rotate in and out of different countries as senior managers they are generalist who often do not have the expertise of the position they fill. It is a place of who you know rather than what you know

review_title: Excellent company, good worklife balance and open culture
pros:
I had worked in HSBC GLT pune for more than 5 years as a Tester.
GLT is a fun place to work, the hikes are decent at every level you can expect a double digit hike.
Variable component is very good, at an experience more than 4 yrs you can expect Variable of more than 1 Lacs.
GLT organizes various outdoor and indoor activities through out the year which gives you a lot of time to rejuvenate
.
cons:
Onsite opportunities should be more as after 4-5 yrs of experience an IT professional looks out for an Onsite where GLT lags a bit.
Some Managers favors their regional candidates which I think happens everywhere.

job_title: PPI Complaints Handler in Southampton, England
pros: The best thing about the place is the people. Everyone is really friendly. free tea and coffee. Nice work life balance if you do 4 days but if you work on shifts it's a bit rubbish.
cons: Not a lot of room for development, the work gets quite boring once you know what you're doing. You have to apply for a permanent position for the job you are doing! If someone else gets the job because of a better interview then you have to train them to do your job!! Ludicrous 😂 also avoid joining PBA! No recognition in the jobs either, because they get worried they may upset someone else!

review_title: Working at HSBC Securities Services Ireland
pros: Working at a good location in the Docklands, beautiful new offices.  There is an average salary range.  Reimbursement for education costs is offered.  Skillsoft training is available online in office or at home.  It is a stable company.  There were a small number of employees laid off in recent credit crunch.  Management offered one day of unpaid leave to employees to save money and avoid further layoffs.
cons: There is not much opportunity for pay increase or promotion.  We have long working hours at busy times.  The HR team is invisible and ineffective with respect to representing employee issues.

review_title: Unbelivable beurocracy, Poor Management , no strategy.
job_title: Vice President Business Banking in New York, NY
pros:
Pay check, resume builder, intl banking experience. 
 Other parts of the bank away from the business banking channel may be better.
cons: This place is in shambles, management team is pompous and out of touch.  Middle management will not push back to upper mngt when expectations are super human.  Most of the processes here are broken, negative customer impact is very high.  I can not say enough bad things about this segment at HSBC.  If you are thinking about getting a job with business banking, please ask around first, talk to a current employee.  You will be better off at Citi, Chase, boa, wells, or a midtier bank.

pros: Generally the people are quite nice and laid back. It is beneficial especially if you need to complete a qualification such as ACA, CFA or part-time masters.
cons: Things are run pretty inefficiently there and the pay is almost always below the industry's average... They keep pushing for this flat and transparent hierachy, which ultimately means no promotion until you are almost retired. If you have the luck of working in the headquarter, unless a) you work in one of the 3 trading floors and b) you come to work during those god forbidden hours (very early in the morning, very late at night or weekends), fighting for the lift can be quite a nausea experience. In some departments, you will find these obscenely well-paid contractors who don't add much value.

pros:
Salary is on par with market and in most cases above industry average if you compare with services companies. The variable pay is outside of your CTC. if you are a PM or AVP you can add min 2-3 lakhs ad variable pay to your CTC. The annual hike is decent at. 10-15% based your performance.

WFH option and flexible work timing helps strike a good work life balance. 

Mandatory 2 weeks leave in a year and best part is as per policy no one can call you for office related work.
cons:
It's a bank and an old one so expect process to be slow. But the bank is working towards overcoming this. 

Large number of people doing small bits of work hence it takes time for you to get the bigger picture.

pros: A multi national bank with good facility,high pay, employee engagement programs, great vision and mission, great sessions like At our best, for personality development
cons: but really loot of employee patient level. The senior the management is, the unprofessional they get. My manager was never a guy who thought for employee , even not for retention. It's will every manager. No one takes up responsibility , no one is open dependable or connected which are the vision of HSBC. Ownership is not into this work enviournment. Once you step into the office, you will start regretting from the first day to the last day

review_title: Work Life Balance is Great, Salary Might Not Be That Competitive
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Manila, Manila
pros: Work life balance is great. You can take leaves as long as it's within the policy. If it is, it's almost a no questions asked approved leave. Most managers discourage overtime. If there are multiple hours of overtime rendered, management takes notice and works on it. Phones are allowed on the floor which is something different from other service centers. Sleeping quarters, gym, play area, karaoke rooms, and pantries are great.
cons: The salary might not be competitive anymore. I have heard some of my colleagues leaving the company for a better pay outside. The company needs to review it's compensation package. It might be great for people coming from outside. But if you are growing within the company, the increase is okay - but not competitive.

review_title: Nice people, decent perk for Senior staff but lots of red tape, politics and too much staff.
job_title: APAC Director In Equities in Hong Kong
pros: Decent salaries, good name/brand in Hong Kong. nice benefit for Directors and above that pays up to 95% of tuition fees for up to 2 children, much easier to move internally than in US banks.
cons: Long hours, little respect from London staff despite Asia generating 90% of revenues worldwide, lots of red tape and inefficient processes like the ridiculous number of approvals required to do anything. Too many admin processes exist as insurance policies for incompetent staff.

pros: The 401k matching is one of the best.  Health Care choices plentiful.  Salary very competitive for the area. Lot's of opportunity for growth due to the sheer size of the organization. Relocations plentiful, particularly international opportunities
cons: "Top down" communication sorely lacking. "Offshore" is  becoming the new "Onshore"  Pay for performance, although a highly touted concept is still just a tagline. Disparity of treatment on the employee level.  Goals  are vague, mostly unmeasurable, and often used as a punishment rather than incentive.  Internal job posting program is mostly one way  commnication with little or no feedback to even acknowledge acceptance of interest on the applicants part.

review_title: OK place to be, but there are better places to grow your career
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Good work / life balance and benefits.  The people are down to earth and generally approachable.  People below management level will, for the most part communicate openly and honestly with you.  I have found my direct management very accomodating to my personal needs.  I rarely have to put any time in on weekends.  There are some talented individuals, but management has not found the glue to put it together.
cons: Lack of senior management communication and leadership qualities.  Communication from local senior management is weak and infrequent.  The troops are not inspired and have not been since the day I arrived.  HR is disorganized and unresponsive

pros: Great room for advancement, employees really care about and work hard towards company goals and everyone is very friendly.  Location is fantastic, and the new offices are quite lovely.
cons: This company loves to perform massive layoffs, usually based on salary cap alone.

pros:
Good benefits and annual leaves
Large international bank with good internal-transfer opportunities
Multicultural environment
Great career path and quick growth if your position allows...although sometimes you can't get more responsibility even when you ask for it
cons:
Jobs divided into many small departments so exposure to new things is minimal, not ideal for growth in most departments

Too large an organisation, therefore more discussion than action, especially in regional roles. Nothing much really happens here.

Big teams, unimportant work, etc. You would have to be quite lucky to be in a position where you're doing meaningful work that can showcase your talent and be noticed. This really varies between departments and depends on your manager.

pros: Really hard to get fired. HR wouldn’t fire someone who recently committed a typically fireable offense, and said “you have to give them a second chance”
cons:
Low pay that is way below market. Variable comp lacks all other banks on the street. With low risk appetite, HSBC has 0 competitive advantage outside of being “global.” Weak product offering with poor clients who would never ask HSBC to lead on any important deals. 

Commercial banking (CMB) pay is very below market. Graduates start at $65k, whereas other grads in banks (think Citi, JPM, even DB) start at 85k 

Most first year analysts from outside hires get 70k, again below market. 

Bonuses in 2018 were 6% after HUGE cuts for no reason, despite the bank doing $20 billion in profits. Most banks on street pay more for back/middle office support in both fixed and variable compensation.

Promotions are hard to come by, usually don’t amount to much of a raise. GCB system is worthless

job_title: Leadership Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: San Diego location was ideal. Call center employed many local residents. Home office in Illinois was more advanced when it came to training facilities and programs to advance the skills of the leadership teams.
cons: Management support for training not really there. Promotions within the San Diego office were questionable. The human resources team must have been a "green" team without much experience. I witnessed interactions and conversations that should have been held as confidential that were discussed openly. This did not create an environment that compelled associates to reach out to the human resources group when a problem really did occur.  The HR Director at the time was very stringent and I did not see her becoming a business partner with other leaders at the site.

pros:
Very good visibility across all of HSBC group entities
International opportunities, group policies 
Employee Recognition programs
cons:
Bulk of critical decisions are taken by thr group and there have been instances where they had not taken local factors into consideration.
Communication from Senior Mangement in difficult times is not always cleear and timely which creates lot of anxiousness and people living on the edges tend to move out.

pros: The work was interesting and the company name is well known and looks good on a resume. They seem to believe strongly in trial by fire, as their training on new systems or proprietary systems is very lack-luster.
cons: Management and objectives are all over the place. They don't seem to have clear goals from year to year except to maintain the status quo with aging systems and IT infrastructure as a whole. From a top down perspective, it seems as if there is a lot of talk about things, but no one really taking action to make things happen, even when things are necessary. They are very reactive to problems instead of pro-active to ensuring problems do not happen.

job_title: Financial Advisor in New York, NY
pros:
A lot of freedom in your schedule
Some colleagues are pleasant
Enjoyed my first few years there
Had a small pension plan
cons:
Pushing product became the name of the game. 
Didn't care about their clients 
Always had bad news in the paper which made you question the company. 
The brokerage arm was like the step-child of the bank. 
Bankers weren't properly incentivized to help drive investment activity.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
pros:
Good benefit package.
Some great internal training and network groups.
Some interesting projects working with global teams.
Flexible working usually available.
Access to wider HSBC initiatives, including community involvement.
Broad spectrum of roles across different business functions which are in theory accessible to all employees.
cons:
Your working environment is entirely dependent on who your head of department is - seems obvious to say, but culture can change overnight with an internal restructure.
Processes, controls, governance are over cumbersome and can severely impact project timelines - there is a lack of acceptance from stakeholders that this is a real issue.
Real issue of staff being managed out if face doesn't fit, despite amount of internal leadership training.

review_title: Some Good, Some Bad. HSBC is a Good Place to Work.
job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist III in Brandon, FL
pros: I was with HSBC nearly 16 years. The pay was good and so were the benefits. There was life work balance and the work schedule was flexible.  Ample paid time off and was available. The company was solid and I am proud to be an HSBC alumni.
cons: I worked in the subprime mortgage area that HSBC bought from Household. HSBC did not want to service these loans and once the market rebounded sufficiently from the crash in 2008, HSBC began selling off the portfolio of loans. That resulted in my lay off this past May.  The site where I worked will be closed, if not already.

job_title: PPI Complaint Handler in Southampton, England
pros:
4 day a week shifts 
Nice lunch room 
Great snacks on birthdays 
Nothing about the job nor managers or procedures
cons: Moved from role to role, very clicky- if you weren’t in the click you didn’t have a chance to of being taken seriously. Don’t look at individuals results go over popularity, bad attitudes from managers, not caring and no training given when you start. Appalling company to work for. Now starting new role realised how badly they treat their staff.

pros: Great Compensation, Global Opportunity, Advancement, if you are willing to relocate or live in particular areas of country.
cons: Do not always do what they say, they preach a "joined up" attitude or "onehsbc" but areas of the business do not even speak to each other.  Dealing with the customer service, it is terrible.  Most of it is off shored to India, Phillipines, or Pakistan.  This slows responses due to lack of understanding, communication, job skill, time zones or just a plain lack of caring or understanding.

review_title: HSBC - Striving to be the employer of choice
job_title: Customer Service & Sales Associate in Tulsa, OK
pros: HSBC is constantly striving to be a leader for both the customers and the employees. I feel the pay is above average compared to similar jobs in the area as well the benefits that HSBC offers are second to none.
cons: With the economy the way it is now there are many changes taking place. The upper management isn't communicating with the employees if the changes are going to affect them and how. This is leading to speculation that the site is going to close as did one of the other sites recently.

review_title: A Place to Learn and Grow with Many Buts
pros:
A good place to gather experiences from areas such as planning, estimation, resource destribution, project management althought not always in the positive scenarios but learning from "what not to do"s is also a good experience to have and carry on to future careers.

The brand is sound and widely known and could act as a stepping stone to further one's career.
cons:
The pay is not always the best.  Be prepared to work long and odd hours.

The management/business really need to know what directly they are heading to and clearly define a path for the rest of the team to follow.

review_title: No the best in term of exposure to cutting edge technology, but a good experience learning about robust banking systems
pros:
Part of one of the world's largest financial organizations
Global exposure - almost every project will have international clients
Great Facility in the heart of the city
Number of employee engagement initiatives and great CSR activities
Good work life balance
cons:
Being a bank - not the first to try cutting edge technologies
Learning opportunities may be limited
You may not get to work with the smartest brains

pros: Benefits are on par with other banks (or slightly better). Hours are not too bad in general.
cons: As the name calls, it is a bureaucratic workplace stuff with generation of 50-60s. People tend to stick with groups whom they know for ages, rather than accepting new comers in a welcoming open-minded manner. Reluctant to change. Government like culture i.e. people go to work just to prepare for their retirement. Not an exciting place for people who want stimulation. To be fair, it may also depends on your boss's mindset. If you get an open-minded boss, you are lucky. But luck just doesn't appear in every team.

review_title: Used to be fantastic. Not any more
pros: The staff are a fantastic bunch of people to work with. The facilities are generally pretty good for a call centre with decent areas for relaxation at break times.
cons: Sell sell sell. This is all that seems to matter nowadays. Bonuses are reducing year on year and even staff breaks are being reduced from 15 mins to 10

review_title: Challenging place to make a difference
pros: Pay is good; benefits are not as good as they once were but are still ok.
cons: It is a disaster in the compliance area; so many new hires.  Nepotism/favoritism at the highest levels within the compliance area without regard for capability.   So many people starting from ground 0; with no experience.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Chicago, IL
pros: The company is flexible with the occasional telecommuting needs employees may have. Employees have options to transfer within the organization, across departments, cities or even countries.
cons: While a open space seating arrangement may encourage collaboration, we are not all created equal: some of us are in Sales and speak and socialize loudly, others of us need to be on the phone for long periods of time, all during the time some of us need to focus on something else. Vacation and sick days are in the same pool, which may discourage some from using them for sick days. The organization is growing in the US and some departments may be more organized than others.

pros:
None so far work is not that great!!
some people have good work life balance like a govt job but its really irritating when your colleagues are not quick as your are!!
cons:

job_title: Fraud Prevention Specialist in Depew, NY

job_title: Senior Analyst in New Castle, DE
pros: The benefits are great and dependent upon your manager, the work/life balance exceeds expectations.
cons: The high level management seems to be moving the company in a good direction, however, somewhere the translation of their vision gets lost within the senior to mid level management sector.  Implementation of any vision is limited to the committment level of the mid-level management.

review_title: Not a great place to start a career but if you want to retire...
pros: Great reputation in Hong Kong. This bank provides good benefits, able to work flexible hours, work life balance is encouraged.  The bank supports many charity and environmental activities.
cons: Development of trainees is very lacking and dependant on which manager/department you work for though they have now put in a development program to help with this.  Bank is very bureaucratic!  Pay is much lower than market. A lot of people staying back late but not very productive - have a mentality of needing to be seen staying back.  Management style very old fashioned.

pros: The pay is fairly decent.  The company offered nice benefits which were very competitive compared to other similar companies.  Time off was also good.
cons: Too big in many ways so one group often wasn't in sync with another regarding company objectives.  Company demanded a lot and you were subject to a lot of lunch time meetings and late meetings past 5pm.  Too many emails, sametime messages, and meetings which interfered getting work done during the day.  Too much red tape.  The business often did not know their own business.

review_title: In Banking, one of the best places to work
pros:
1. Good Exposure
2. Excellent Client Base
3. Good Support Systems
4. Transparent Promotion Policies
5. Best Compensation In-Class
6. Employee Friendly HR policies
cons:
While the promotion policies are transparent they may appear to be at times dogmatic and there would be no relaxation on any account. This may lead to a stagnation in some cases and thus dissatisfaction.
Due to recent economic conditions abroad (outside India) there have been large scale cost cutting and this has been a big let down for the old employees, so there is a general sense of resentment in the company circles.

pros:
1. Salary compensation and annual hikes are good.
2. One can enjoy complete work life balance. WFH option available in some of the teams.
3. Good career opportunities if you want to switch through internal job postings.
4. Friendly colleagues and managers. Nice work environment
5. HR policies are good. Caring organisation with lots of HR initiatives.
6. Leave policy is good. You get annual 10 days compulsory core leave apart from other leaves. Some may not like it.
cons:
1. Senior management is hardly concerned about employees' issues. Takes poor decisions at times.
2.  So called "Quality initiative" is impacting employees satisfaction due to increasing work related stress and pressure.
3. Managers are diplomatic. Speak something else and do what they want to do.

job_title: General Banking Officer in Hong Kong
pros:
Benefits are okay, transparent overtime compensation scheme,
trainings are enough, 5-day work.
cons:
1. Your job is to reach quotas for EVERYTHING. Number of accounts you create, number of credit cards, number of clients you have met per day, number of transactions you have done as a teller, amount of insurance premium from your clients, number of referrals to relationship managers, amount of mortgages drawdown, number of "warm calls" made; and even when it comes to something not related to the business such as the number of votes for some kind of service award.

2. The objective of point number 1 above, is to make your branch perform good, thus satisfying the division management team's ambition to compete with each other, so they can further please the far upper management levels.

pros:
- provides some banking and credit card packages free of charge to employees
- stable
- great benefit package and lots of holidays even for a part time.  Full time employees who worked for several years at HSBC have 20-25 days of paid holidays
cons:
- not a lot of growth at retail banking level
- part time personal bankers (tellers) are very part time, some even get 10 hours per week at my branch
- lots of weird/angry customers to deal with, but this is the same for all retail jobs I would suppose

pros:

- very very human working hours
- salary and benefits
- working from home is a norm
- not very stressful environment
- strong graduate program

- approach to conduct / culture is bringing you back to 90s which, again, is no longer where the industry is at
- senior management stuck in the same roles for years
- lack of collaboration, very hierarchical, cumbersome and ineffective management structure 
- product proposition is very weak compared with competitors

pros:
Opportunities world-wide for mobile individuals
Vast array of technologies to learn
Colleagues are fantastic

Continuous layoffs for past several years
Constantly asked to do more with less
Ever changing senior management in some areas

review_title: Good safe harbor in turbulent times, but not a place to grow or learn
job_title: Investment Banking Vice President in New York, NY
pros: At least in  theory, the firm supports a work life balance that is unusual for an investment bank.  In practice however, face time is still expected by immediate management.
cons: No clear strategic focus in the firm, very high turnover in line management.  I banking heads would be switched out every year.

review_title: HSBC is a strong International Company with opportunities, even in cautious economic times.
pros: Large International company with many opportunities.  One of the more stable financial institutions in the world.  Great benefits and opportunities.  I work in the IT department, there are some very well qualified people.  HSBC has improved over the past 2 years with work / life balance (working remote, flex hours, etc.)
cons: Hard to move up if you're in a smaller group.  Outsourcing more work.  Due to the economy, they have had some cut-backs.

review_title: I have had the ability to move into several positions over the years and work my way up.
pros: As a global institution we can support our business and personal customers on an international basis which creates some job security and opens other career oppertunities.
cons: Very high demands of employess, unrealistic expectations for sales goals. Sr management makes "number" decisions based on a goal they want to attain rather than improvements in existing numbers. There is a big disconnect between expectation and reality.

job_title: Asistente De Servicios Al Cliente in Buenos Aires
pros: good salary, some excellents peers, my direct boss is excelent, as guide and as friend, I adore my job, I like to help people to resolve their problems
cons: Many times there are bad branch managers, specialy mine, he is not qualified to lead a branch or tu have people in charge. There is no relationship between the service that the bank promotes with  the number of workers it has in the branches and leaves much to be desired attention we can provide to customers, since the systems are obsolete

review_title: Lateral hires earn much more than loyals

Used to be known for good work life balance.
In some pockets having very dependable managers.
cons:
Getting infested with lots of politics with new management hires.
Replacing low wage workers with high wage workers due to nepotism.

review_title: "Your future with HSBC is [not in the US]" -- CEO, HSBC North America, May 2009 -- It shows in the over 12000 jobs cut
pros: Mettawa facility is very nice--gym, great cafeteria, open work space plan.  Benefits package is satisfactory.  Salaries for managers and below will be in the medium range of the market. If you are internationally mobile, many opportunities exist.

Exceptionally political environment-- unfairness in promotions an ongoing company-wide issue with employees.  Workload is onerous due to under staffing. Training is online and most trainers have been let go, as have most employee communications people.

pros: If you're looking for a overtly "stable" no tension non aggressive place to work - this is it. They do have some of the best HR practices though and are located in civilization as against the dark side of the moon in Hinjewadi!
cons: If you're looking for speed, learning & world class professionalism - this is NOT the place to be. Plus you need to be an old timer - newbies will find it hard to break through the old boy network as knowing the "right" people is important.

pros:
You would rarely see yourself working beyond the shift timings
Good Hike and relatively better bonus

6. AVP's handle teams but you can hardly see them as people managers

job_title: Corporate Accounting in New York, NY
pros: The opportunity to work with some incredible people who were passionate about what they do. Global opportunities can exist for those willing to seek them out.

review_title: A group of good people scared to make a decision
pros:
Ability to work abroad. 
Benefits package.
Staff loans.

They are politicians.
cons: Good for dumb and low IQ people who fear competition.

review_title: Just doing our job, while we still have one.
job_title: Client Development in Prospect Heights, IL
pros:
Large company with tremendous amounts of influence that it's able to leverage domestically and internationally.  

Great benefits and new programs geared towards work-life balance has steadily improved moral.
cons:
Unstable and unpredictable job security.  We've experience re-orgs at least twice annually in the past 2-3 years.

Compensation and review/rating methodology is flawed and is more of a cost cutting tool than anything.

review_title: Work here only as a temporary place
pros: Goof place if you are interested in an international opportunity as the bank has a lot of offices all around the world. It is very difficult to find a secondment though and only the most networked employees with tons of patience can find something.
cons: No career prospects in Salinas. Very limited training available to employees and all learning has to be due to self-initiative. The culture of the bank is very much driven by "don't ask too many questions in senior management meetings" or you are considered to be disrespectful.

review_title: Solid brand, good training, good for starting out your career
pros: They place a lot of emphasis on training graduates and new comers, lots of opportunities to move internally between departments and internationally. People are friendly and helpful, good culture and people are proud to be part of the organisation.
cons: Mainly challenges due to recent regulations which have impacted the sector. The bank is particularly conservative in its approach which sometimes makes it harder to keep up with fierce competion, which is more aggressive in going out and getting new business.

pros:
Good allocation of days, 20 to start off and can allocate them in which ever way you want whether it be sick day or PTO.

Good balance, come in on time, leave on time as long as you get your work done.

Average benefits, Average pay unless outside of privte bank.

Simple and easy Trade compliance system for day traders.

Would recommend to others BUT not in private bank sector.
cons:
Dated tech, IBM mainframe (black screen, green text)
Close knitted group consisting of spanish speakers.
90% team leads / managers are women.
lack of tech savvy people.
Build your relationships with selected few to get things done in smoother fashion.
Lack of team player qualities for those who have been years ago. Tend to drill you down on small errors rather than the big picture.

pros: HSBC has around 6,600 offices in 80 countries and territories across Africa, Asia, Oceania, Europe, North America and South America, and around 60 million customers.
cons: HSBC is organised within four business groups: Commercial Banking; Global Banking and Markets (investment banking); Retail Banking and Wealth Management; and Global Private Banking.[12]

pros:
- Health benefits are excellent.
- Time off is okay once you hit your fifth year.
- Excellent hours.
cons:
- Pay needs to be higher. 
- Company burned their relationships with clients and lost business due to bad business decisions.
- Managers treat staff like they are nobody of importance.
- Managers hold back employees for selfish reasons.
- Company hasn't given annual raises in years.

review_title: I am very proud to work for HSBC
job_title: People Support Manager in London, England
pros: Senior people leaders who are passionate about their people and customers.  HSBC UK Bank have an exciting culture and strategy. There are lots of opportunities to develop and succeed in your career.  I've had the best managers who inspire me and believe in me; they are also funding my professional qualifications and investing in my development.  I feel very proud to work at HSBC.
cons: Like any very large organisation, we need to work harder to collaborate internally and innovate, although the most senior people have the right mindset to do this and are innovating.  It's very exciting to be part of it!

pros: Great place to work if you want to work in emerging markets.  Vast global organization provides opportunities in  many areas and functions.  Conservative nature works well in current environment.  Very stable company.  People that can adapt to the HSBC Group way can do very well.  IM program is best way to move up fast and get best assignments.
cons: Limited focus in the US.  Not a great understanding of the US market or of consumer finance by Group executives.  Very conservative, which leads to limited growth potential in up markets.  More focused on process and central decision making.  Taking decisions out of front line managers.

review_title: Large company not in touch with its employees.
pros: Diverse culture, tuition reimbursement and 401k benefits, generous amount of vacation days.
cons: Company is so large, that employees feel like a number.  Management continuously implements new procedures without getting feedback from employees first, causing many problems with the process that have to be patched along the way.  Employee advocacy is almost non existent.  Middle management continues to throw employees under the bus to make themselves look better.  Barely any leadership found in middle management.  Communication between departments that rely on each other is terrible.  Roles and responsibilities are unclear.  Very difficult for young professionals to move up in the organization even if they are top performers.

pros: One needs to really self train which in turn makes you an independent thinker.
cons: They do not request feedback on Sr Managers, who in turn have gotten into their roles by taking the credit for others.  The lack of understanding for other cultures was outstanding given that this is an international company. The work environment is quite toxic due to review structure and promotes an anti-team culture.

review_title: Highly structured organization but not good for upward mobility
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Hong Kong
pros: There are a lot of supporting functions and systems that enable you to get your business going and deliver your performance. You can accumulate the valuable experience in engaging in deals involving Group offices in other countries, which is essential for employees nowadays to understand better different business cultures.
cons: Very hierarchical. You aren't expected to move up the corporate ladder to the management, in particular if you do not enter the company as a Management Associate--no matter how good your CV is. Also, it is not decisive enough to cut down the certain types of business it intends to cease, leaving the front office staff in a difficult position to reject client's request without a solid reason.

review_title: Working at a Bank is not Easy
job_title: Software Business Consultant (Architect) in Tampa, FL
pros: World class experiences with product owners, customers, and other parts of an international company.  Market compensation and many chances to move within the company.  You can experience a lot here.
cons: Change is at a slow scale.  New projects will take at least a year to complete.  In the US there is a high degree of regulation so the US has little mobility.  If you can get to Canada, HK or the UK then there are more opportunities.

review_title: Great company to work for but in order to move up the latter it's who you know.
job_title: Senior Business Information Analyst in Mettawa, IL
pros: How successful you are here is determine by how much you put into it.  In other words if you work long hours and have a "get it done" attitude then you'll do fine.  They do emphasize work life balance so you are given plenty of family time.  Actually, if I recall correctly you must take a mandatory one week vacation.  No email or anything work related is allowed during this week.  That's always a nice thing.
cons: I really didn't experience anything I would consider negative working at HSBC.  I was treated right and really enjoy my job.  It's a shame I had to leave.

pros: Training opportunities OUTSIDE the credit operations. A variety of activities and networking events and great for personal development. Good medical and health benefits. Good retirement benefits. 2 days of sick leave per monthly without the need to provide medical certificate and birthday leave. Lot of internal job opportunities. Good work / life balance.
cons: As for the working environment in Credit Operations, there is no formal training but on-the-job training, keep being pushed by front line, lack of career progression and personal development is not emphasised. Low-level manager and team leaders are not good at management and leading, using authoritative style and not inspiring. Surrounded by very experienced and loyal colleagues who are not ambitious for career development and it is dominated by married 40 plus women.

review_title: Cronyism is rife and commonly practiced
pros: Overall an interesting company but it is a shame they have so many bad people working in management roles where cronyism is rife and common practice.
cons:
Cronyism is rife and commonly practiced.  There is a common pattern of managers hiring friends and colleagues into roles for which are not best qualified and do not deserve.  They secure the role because they are friends with the recruitment manager.  In particular a pattern of hires from a renowned failed British bank is lowering the standards.  I was forced out of my role after a short time to make way for one such hire.

In house resident temp recruiter Resource Solutions is extremely poor.  They churn out countless jobs but NEVER response to applications.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
pros:
Beautiful office
Interesting people from a variety of backgrounds 
Good compensation
cons:
Terrible internal communications
no commitment to employees
no clarity on structure. 
This may have just been the department I worked it but I doubt it; and the fact that I don't know says a vast amount about how complicated their set up is! Also if you do decide to work here - pay attention to your payslips; you'd think a bank would handle this process smoothly but they do not (so many tax mistakes!) and you will not get help from HR once you leave!

job_title: Senior Risk Analyst in Buffalo, NY
pros: Decent compensation.  Ability to work from home.  Friendly direct managers.
cons: Work is pigeonholed.  Management assumes your current responsibilities is all that your capable of —> difficult to move over/up.  Poor HR personnel.  Too much offshores as far as work.  Exec Management cares too much about shareholder return instead of employees, leads to constant revised goals, policies and standards.

review_title: Good work-life balance, Okay Salary, Less innovation (Subject to project-project)

review_title: Hang in there - still a good place to be

cons: Some workplace environments need a little work particularly the older buidings. It shouldn't be underestimated how important the little things are for maintaining morale

Bad luck if you got the mean one since only 3/10 team leader are cool and chill. Some days you'll be dragging your feet to work. After a while of getting higher and higher paycheck you starts to feel like nobody and the work stresses you out  lot.

job_title: Fraud Detection Specialist in Vancouver, BC
pros: It has a lot of job openings in a variety of areas throughout the company. As an international company it offers openings in many countries within the group. It offers good Time-Off benefits and health care benefits.
cons: At the same time, it carries all the unwieldiness of most large corporations. The jobs are very specialised and are fairly narrowed down in its context. It also faces a lot of IT issues which often gets in the way of the job. The metrics used for measuring performance are also sometimes unfair and does not encourage quality work.

pros:
- work-life balance 
- good environment 
- hike and bonus are good in some years but recently they are cutting down the cost so for many employees zero hike and zero bonus for 2017.

job_title: AML Compliance Officer in New York, NY

As I witness first-hand, the single goal of these chronically under qualified employees then became keeping up the charade that they had the requisite skill set to handle these management roles.  The charade often included over reliance on more capable, more junior management and staff as well as throwing other staff "under the bus" in order to save their skin.  Suffice to say it created a toxic environment where I had zero trust or confidence in many in management.

review_title: Flexible schedules, yet short sighted business employement strategies

Moving towards temporary staff hiring  load both locally and offshored. Senior executive roles are externally sourced from other companies or global countries.

pros: Learned a great deal about site management, online marketing, customer and user experience. Great benefits. Work/life balance was great.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY

review_title: worked for hsbc for about 9 years. I was a retail banking manager and a corporate banking manager.

cons: Mangement discrimination with employees ad mangement self interests do exist unfortunately.

pros: I've been with the company for almost 5 years now, being here I have had so much opportunity to move around and expand my experience in different departments. cons: As in mostly every business, it's who you know to advance in here. My theory is you never know who is going to be your boss next so just be nice and respectful to everyone and you may have a chance to move up within the company.

Work in a multi cultural environment
Extensive repository of banking domain knowledge bank

Frequent 'strategy' changes
Plateau'd career for people with 15+ years of workex

job_title: Senior Project Manager in New York, NY

Rotational scheme. You get knowledge on Risk, Sales, Products and operations throughout the rotations. Structure of scheme isn't completely set out and HR can take time to properly organise the rotations.
cons:
High work load, very stressful environments. 
Expectations of what you need to do each day get higher and higher and if you do not reach these it will go against your performance. 
No support given whilst in work or training.

pros: Salaries are on time, renowned brand,

A & V Team for Dublin (Sri Lanka) is the worst. Finance and Accounting people please don't waste your time. some times they create false information to for the sake of saving them selves from their Jobs. HSBC brand is a real trap in Sri Lanka don't fall for it. company is massively cuttings costs and unprofitable, and employee turnover ratio is sky high.

review_title: Great workplace, amazing vision... and dreadful upper management

cons: When most of your colleagues have worked here for many many years, it is hard to be promoted.

job_title: Customer Service Officer in Gurgaon, Haryana

pros: Work life balance,  employee benefits oriented , culture, environment , bonus structure . Excellent place for females to work .

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Buffalo, NY

cons: I my experience I'm not sure if the compensation is as good as other banks in the United States.  I don't necessarily know if employees are extremely visible to senior management since the company is so big.

Poor quality people around you
Too much politics.

Branch manager's are promoted because of their sales numbers, not because they have management experience or know how to motivate and train.  My branch manager was cussed out by two employees and a third quit citing her micro-managerial style as the reason.

job_title: Senior Marketing Analyst in Charlotte, NC

cons: Took a while to get into a decent salary range.  Hit hard by the financial services meltdown, but since they got out of mortgage they have a stronger future.  Was laid off from the mortgage division, but was able to get a great severance package.

Very slow adopters of change - due to a combination of technology, process and people

pros:
Competitive pay, satisfactory benefits package
Attainable and reasonable sales goals
"Laissez Faire" sales environment
Universally recognized banking brand
International focus

The salary for an HSBC BRB is higher (on average) than the same position at a competing bank, but the incentive pay is lower.  

Sales goals are appropriate and achievable for talented BRB's: HSBC is not a widget-based bank; they are focused on quality, not quantity.  Instead of 5 checking accounts per day like some of the competing domestic banks require of their salespeople, HSBC wants its sales force focusing on cross-selling insurance, investments and credit products to its existing affluent client base and prospecting for commercial accounts. 

Management is not constantly breathing down your neck nor are they micromanaging (as long as you are proactive and are hitting your monthly numbers).  They also encourage (and technically, mandate) self-written insurance and investments where other banks are stripping their employees of this responsibility and placing the burden entirely on the Financial Advisor.  An unlicensed personal banker is a mere order taker, and serves little purpose to their branch, short of account opening, service and maintenance.  An HSBC BRB truly has the opportunity to present his or her clients with a holistic banking proposition: checking, savings, credit, insurance and investments all with a global banking platform.
cons:
Ridiculously stifling compliance culture
"Not my job" attitude across many departments
Constantly changing procedures
Laughably overpaid managers 
Too many "Vice-Presidents"
Outdated computer systems
Conflicting answers/directives from the same departments
No good deed goes unpunished

It's all right there.

review_title: A large corporation - NOT an Investment Bank
pros: Most people are friendly, there is a nice atmosphere - much less aggressive than most other trading floors.  The benefits are pretty good and competitive with what other banks are offering (good pension, holidays, private medical care).  The gym in the London HQ is very nice for a cost of 25-30% of what you'd pay externally for a decent gym.  There is a good work-life balance, even in Global Banking and Markets (the investment banking division).   HSBC is slow to make massive redundancies, so there is more job security in tough times.  Overall, if you aren't concerned about developing your career or making serious money, then this is a pleasant and easy place to work with decent base salaries and good benefits.
cons: This is not really an investment bank, it's rather more as I would imagine it would be working at British Telecom or British Gas.  Extremely conservative organisation - you will not get ahead by rocking the boat or trying to do something in a new or different way (this is in fact one of the few things that might get you sacked).  In order to get approval to do anything, you have to go through about 3 or 4 committees.  There is very little encouragement to develop your career or move up in the bank - you have to fight your way up and this is nearly impossible if you are not a white British man.  The bonuses are shockingly low compared to what competitors are paying (in Capital Markets).  Very few people, particularly in senior management that you can look up to - most of them just seem to be bureaucrats.  In general, there are a lot people who don't do much work, but sit around from 9am-4pm and collect a salary (they were probably ambitious at some point until HSBC crushed it out of them).  There is very little incentive to put in a lot of effort - it will not be rewarded.

pros: Benefits and flexible work schedule are a real plus.  Staff genuinely try their best and I have always experienced my coworkers to want to do the right thing.  Average 20-25 days vacation to start but this time is also used for sick time.  However, if one is sick for more than 3 days, short term disability is available.
cons: Expected to give a lot of yourself to succeed.  Can be draining and very competitive workplace.  There is a 20/70/10 performance policy which is essentially a bell curve that can be de motivating.

pros:
Work / life balance is OK. Employees at my level are actively encouraged to work from home 1, 2 or 3 days per week. During the day there's a lot of freedom to go about doing your thing without having people hover over you. As an employee you're treated as an adult with appropriate give and take.

The company is also by far the most global I've ever been a part of. Many companies claim to be global by nature of having offices everywhere. But at HSBC there is far more global collaboration than what I've experienced elsewhere. If you serve your time, there are opportunities to move internationally as well. The majority of people I work with are not from Canada even though we all work out of the same office now.

On the whole, corporate values are fairly open. Right now for example, HSBC is sponsoring a few events for World Pride. Internally there are posters encouraging employees to participate in Pride events as well. World Cup 2014 is currently in full swing in Brazil and many employees are taking full advantage of excellent TV coverage to watch games, participate in pools etc. So there is definitely a light-hearted aspect of HSBC which is embraced.
cons:
I consider my pay to be low. The time-off policy is not overly restrictive, but it's an oddity to me in that you get x days off (depends on seniority) but if you're sick that counts as time off. So you're not supposed to take 100% of your time off as vacation, but rather leave a day or 2 "in the bank" just in case you get sick.

The biggest con of HSBC Canada though is that there's no sense of urgency in anything and thus no sense of direction. To me it feels like I'm working with a gigantic blob of Jello. The mass kind of jiggles and moves in a direction that's roughly forward, but it's really slow going. And when you contribute your bit, the mass just kind of jiggles some more without really feeling like there's forward momentum. 

Without a sense of urgency, everything just slows down as people ease up. So we end up doing stupid things like creating spreadsheets which then need to be manually copied to Powerpoint which then gets emailed out as an update which no one really pays attention to anyway. But hey - we have a deck and somehow that's perceived as being a Good Thing.

People development does not seem to be a priority either. As a new hire I was thrown 20 or so web-based trainings (which taught me nothing new really) and I got to attend a couple of conference call / trainings. Other than that, I find I need to rely on my own initiative to learn how stuff really works at HSBC and who does what. There is essentially no formal training for on boarding a new employee and as far as I can tell, no policy for internal training let alone external third-party training courses. I suppose if I build a case and ask I might be allowed to attend some course somewhere, but it's up to me and my initiative. I don't think HSBC will proactively initiate training unless it's another web-based compliance thing.

review_title: Large organisation with a very flat management structure.  Hard to get promoted
pros:
The people!  It is a very diverse, multicultural and multinational environment.  You do most of your interaction via video and audio conferences (at least in IT) and you often have no idea which city some of the people on calls are in - could be India, US, Switzerland, China, you name it.  

You need to grow your network and get your name known for good positive work.  This will help you get good feedback and increase your performance review. 

People listen to anyone with good, strong and sound ideas.  Given the size of the organisation, not a lot of emphasis is placed on seniority, and you can quite happily engage with people several bands above and below you.  Just learn to treat everyone with dignity and respect, be brilliant at what you do, and you can make a name for yourself!
cons:
You are not likely to get promoted unless you are very junior.  The career bands are very protected and you have to be exceptional to get moved from GCB5 to 4, and a god to move from a GCB4 - 3!

Bonuses and pay remuneration of late have been quite suppressed, especially if you are a 40% tax payer already.  I had no pay rise for 3 years running with a "strong" rating.   If you are an average employee (70% of the population), you will get a "strong" rating.  "Strong" is just average - thats it.  No matter how clever you are or how hard you work, it is very hard to get recognised as "top", unless you are well connected and spend more time influencing than working.  I have found this quite unfair, as the people recognised are generally the loudest rather than the best.

With interest rates already going up a quarter point and set to rise again, the remuneration and bonus situation could change.

These comments apply to HSBC Finance (the old Household organization located in Prospect Heights, IL, and not necessarily the parent company, headquartered in New York in the United States of America).
cons: Very conservative organization. Hard to generate impact and results. Bias towwards running business as more of the same. Frustrating environment if excellence is important to you to achieve satisfaction.

review_title: It an OK pace to start working
pros: Benefit is great compare to other company, 401K is also great.  Working is the same thing over and over, but can't really complain.
cons: There is always going to politic involve when working at a bank, so it is a given.  All job are the same, but it depend on how you look at it that you can become satisfy

review_title: Good company to learn the business
job_title: Assistant Vice President in North Chicago, IL
pros: Great place to learn business skills. Stable company and great work life balance. Huge discrepancies in pay. So be careful where you join
cons: Sometimes work becomes light. A-type personalities might find going too slow. be prepared for a large company with several layers of management

review_title: The largest bank in the world but still caring for people
pros: HSBC is a great place to work. It is a global corporation in Canada, where local banks dominate the market space. Great salaries, work environment, management and career path. If you do not want to get bored working in one of the big five banks in Canada, come to HSBC and make money!
cons: The brand in not widely recognized in Canada. So, some people may not know what exactly what HSBC stands for.

pros: HSBC has a great brand in most countries. The company provides opportunities to get positions in other countries, enabling you exposure that is very unique. The company has a strong focus on emerging markets, providing opportunities to get exposure into these economies.
cons: Very slow organization, lots of red tape around everything. Not the place for entrepreneurship... Salaries are OK, nothing special, around average. Many people are being promoted just cause they have been there for ages, not cause they are good.

review_title: Valuable resume builder, but rapidly diminishing returns.
pros:
- name recognition
- international opportunities
- learn what it means to work in an extremely large, complex banking organization
cons:
- more of a loose confederation rather than a unified corporate structure
- performance review process is awkward at best and could be considered as disingenuous depending upon the effort your manager applies
- one gets the feeling of an 'Us and Them' attitude when dealing with the Head Office (= London) at times

pros: staff are very friendly and willing to answer as many questions as you have, a number of staff made time to have meetings with me just to answer questions i had about grad programmes
cons: the intern salary was not very much, i flew out to hk to work for them and the salary was only 8000HKD which did not even cover the cost of my accomodation

review_title: Fast Paced Money was great until the end...
pros: In the beginning the money was up for grabs. Positions were being filled at record pace. Everyone was friendly and excited to come to work. Worked well helping with life balance at times if you were interested in another dept lateral movement was commonplace.
cons: Performance based employment unfortunately many people were let go that were often top performers that were just in a slump. When the market changed attitudes went with it. Managers wouldn't listen to employee ideas. eventually they started stealing them for job security. if need be HSBC will close entire facilities to protect the bottom dollar.

job_title: Account Executive in Tijuana, Baja California
pros: Very square and strong company identity.   Full of growing opportunities and simple structure.   Lots of stores and good opportunity to earn more money.     Managers offer very good help and do work well with office culture.
cons: Company values are based on English culture.  Not good since Mexico and England are very different.   Mexican culture is more relaxed and more family oriented.   English are colder and don't mesh very well with mexican culture.   Difficult to understand cultural differences.

review_title: From the heights of the Household acquisition to the depths of DPA....
pros: I won't mention the business unit, but I am a current U.S. employee.  Benefits are average for a gargantuan entity; promotions are for the favored (like so many other companies); personal growth has been good, but not something necessarily attributable to this particular firm; plenty of vacation time...6 weeks + 10 holidays; work from home is embraced by corporate and loathed by much of management; performance reviews are provided but are worthless with personnel rankings predetermined by management; there are annual bonuses even for the lowly but range wildly within/across teams depending on budget and personalities; senior management changes and direction spin like a roulette wheel which provides ample opportunity for do overs; opportunity for travel exists as well as meeting interesting people; salaries are excellent compared to the general population and middling compared to other financial services firms. Yes, these are the pros compared to the cons.
cons: Let me just state that the DPA of 2012 wasn't surprising given the far flung, year after year shenanigans at the bank; the feds velvet hammer triggered an internal shotgun response where a scalpel was/is needed.  In the past my response to 'where do you work?' was met with 'what's that?' Later some would say 'oh I had my mortgage with HSBC' (not happily I should add)....now, I respond by just saying 'computers' and leave it at that. I can not hear the word 'mistake' again without screaming. Oh the shame.  Btw, because I am employed in the U.S. (I won't relocate to to snows of Buffalo) I expect my position to be eliminated as the further building of 'low cost' engagements elsewhere further the institutional rot.

job_title: Customer Service Officer in London, England
pros: The pointless workshops that take you out of work for the day
cons: The pay was rubbish considering the ampunt of work qe have to do and work from the past always crept up which is also work that can go back to 2 years, the meet and greet role was just draining as you had to be on your feet for up to 8 hours a day without rest apart from the hour lunch, staff are treated like slaves and continuoualy puahed to get morgages and the slightest thing that you got qrong you'd be landed in hot water and it was all about uploading mortgages, everything else was irrelevant, the place was a my worst nightmare and im glad that I have left

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Depending on the department, flexible work environment and supportive of employees work/life balance. Good 401k 6% match.
cons: Top heavy and insufficient staff to do the work. Some senior mgrs do not encourage rapport with staff and have no idea of valuable employees since they rely on middle manager feedback. Hence, good people leave the company.  Recent defections of many senior management coupled with many serious regulatory infractions has resulted in downward spiral of company.

review_title: Great People & Benefits, Trying Times for the Bank
job_title: Corporate Banking Analyst in Boston, MA
pros:
- Fantastic culture with opportunities to travel and network globally
- Good work/life balance
- Stimulating work, entrepreneurial in nature
- Hourly pay with OT, YE cash bonus
- 401(k) 6% match on 4% contributions
cons:
- Overly hierarchical, "too many chiefs and not enough indians."
- Deferred prosecution agreement and other regulatory pressure has become overbearing; too many over-complicated, time-intensive processes, coupled with understaffing.

pros: Known brand, team was welcoming and friendly, receptive to folks desiring different roles within the organization, not shy to promote based on performance and experience, offered good RRSP match and health benefits
cons: Lots of bureaucracy, HSBC's fines and increased focus on compliance activity made Investment banking role less appealing (more time spent on compliance regulation, less time in deals), team did not allow working from home (despite it being an HR policy), a lot of complaining and pessimism within the teams due to increased bureaucracy/regulation, bonuses shrank every year, leanly staffed due to the hiring freezes so a person frequently did 2 people's work

pros: The globally recognized name of HSBC

Retaliation on your bonus if you have a dissenting opinion.  Management is hard to change. New ideas not appreciated and escalation is worthless. Put up or shut up is the culture. Lack of diversity in senior management positions

review_title: Decent place to start your career
pros:

-Casual work environment
-Decent place to start out a career, especially if you are thinking of working globally in the future. Depends on what department or group you work for however.

-Still a minor player in Canada

review_title: The honest way of making the business.
pros: Work balance life and respect. Flexitime rules. Possibility of growth in learning. Name of the company well known as one of the leading banks in the world. Management showing interest in making HSBC as a "Best place to work". As a consequence there are efforts in order to explain what the management is doing, what are the aims for the future and what is the current situation. It is also appreciated the interest of periodically asking opinions and making surveys on how they can improve the daily work life. Besides social events and multicultural environment are welcome. The diversity is a value.
cons: Too prudential way of making the business. There is a general conservative attitude often. It helps on negative periods but on the other hand it does not pay once the situation is up again. The management approach is friendly and open but it is uncertain and not clear whether they are really so. Making career locally is not always easily achievable as it is claimed, as it is not only depending on personal hystory and value. It seems there is a standardization downward or upward to avoid discontent. In my view there is no distiction between "talents" and normal workers (at least locally).

review_title: HSBC is a Great Place to Work
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: HSBC is committed to work life balance, actively promoting work-from-home opportunities, encouraging employees to take care of personal issues whenever necessary and allowing time-off and ad-hoc working environments to accommodate all situations.  The benefits are excellent, with HSBC paying a very high proportion of medical and dental and matching 401k contributions at a level higher than most.
cons: Pay is not what it is at Investment Banks.  Facilities are less than top-notch.  The lower level worker talent is not at the level one might expect at a large bank.

review_title: Don't join if you are a techie, good for silly managers...

cons: Management is very stiff; the work environment is political and not welcoming.  The pay is below average for an entry-level CSR role.

review_title: Good Compensation and Work/Life Balance.  Many changes are coming with the retirement of the current CEO, Irene Dorner.
